If you want to do a deeper dive into these topics (which I find super interesting) you can read a more in-depth overview of Yellowâ€™s nested hierarchies of complexity and systems thinking.
And you can find out more about Turquoiseâ€™s holographic integration of life and self, technology and feelings, science and spirit.
As for Coral/Indigo, I couldnâ€™t find an in-depth written description that I liked online, but here is a video with a great overview. 
These are the spaces where I most often live.
  

My Spiritual World â€“ flowing between duality and non-duality (Oneness)
And hereâ€™s the spiritual part of what Iâ€™m up to. Itâ€™s a huge part of my life path, so it gets its own section. I donâ€™t need you to have a religion at all, and I wonâ€™t pressure you to be where I am with it, but I do need you to respect that I experience the world as a mystic, and it would be neat if you enjoy listening to me talk about it..
      * I am very psychic (clairvoyant, clairaudient, clairsentient, precognitive). 
      * I perceive the Light and Love that exists within all things. 
      * Sometimes I play with the light of the world, dancing with the flow of events in the downward current of manifestation at the intersection of dreams and reality. 
      * Within this flow, I often perceive things before they happen, and can sometimes shape the way they unfold.
      * Right now thereâ€™s always a constant awareness of that infinite light, but I go back and forth between experiencing myself as utterly one with it, nothing of my personality there, and then back to experiencing myself as Serena-who-is-one-with-everything. So, still somewhat separate from it, or existing as a smaller self within that greater Self. But more and more, that distinction between self and Self is disappearing, or seems unimportant. Occasionally I experience that there is no difference.
      * My awareness spans multiple dimensions, space-time, other worlds. I can perceive and communicate with entities in these spaces across a large range of energy frequencies. 
      * Minor miracles and uncanny coincidences are frequent events in my world. The improbable is probable in my life. 
      * I do energy healing work with friends and clients, mainly around energy psychology, spiritual development, trauma recovery, personal growth, clearing or upgrading energy anatomy, soul retrieval, past lives, future paths, and getting unstuck. 
      * I also attend to large scale things like clearing the traumatic residue of war, collaborating with friends to avert planetary destruction, helping to anchor divine light to aid large groups of people in leveling-up their state of consciousness and accelerate their spiritual awakening, or helping souls cross over after mass deaths.
      * I also help staff a largish annual ceremony that sustains attendeesâ€™ annual personal development goals with an energy community in the Bay Area of California. A colleague and I are responsible for dreaming in the energies needed for the ceremony and helping to ground those energies into reality to help â€œjuiceâ€ participants' future life changes. My intention is to support the personal awakening and growth of as many people as possible, so that we may change the world for the better. 


What are my flaws? Well, it depends on how you think of them, and I am generally kind to myself about them, but I can see how one or more of these would be deal breakers for some.
      * Chronic health conditions: I have a well-managed autoimmune disorder (currently in full remission, expected lifespan = normal). Perimenopause is a challenge at the moment (insomnia, migraines), but HRT is helping. My current physical pace is slow and steady, except for having fast reflexes. If you want a partner to go running with you, Iâ€™m sorry, that is not me. We could go for walks though. I would love to walk and talk in beautiful places. I like gentle kayaking too. We could also do weight training, or tai chi. Iâ€™m open to finding some mild to moderate physical exercise we could do together. 
      * Keto: Iâ€™m a pretty good cook but Iâ€™ve been doing a keto-ish diet for migraines called the Stanton Migraine Protocol, so food is very low carb these days, with no sugars, so if you want to share a stack of wheat pancakes or to have a vegan partner, that is not me. (I was a raw vegan for a while, but it was too destructive for my particular physiology.) Iâ€™ve lost about 15 lbs so far and am more active than I was last year. Itâ€™s helping with the migraines too.
      * Housekeeping, maintenance, and organization: With my health stuff, I tend to focus more on work, social time, relaxing, and spiritual things when Iâ€™m feeling well, so I am less good at these things, and pay someone to help me. But if I have someone doing chores with me, Iâ€™m happy to chat and clean, or do projects together. 
      * I can be stubborn â€“ but this also makes me persistent, dedicated, and diligent. Mostly I am flexible and adaptable, but there are certain areas where I am immovable, usually having to do with deeply held values.
      * Mental health: While generally happy and in good spirits, I struggled with depression and anxiety for a long time. The inflammation from the autoimmune disorder made it hard to maintain beneficial neurotransmitters. But now that the inflammation is controlled, my mental health is generally good, well managed and regulated, though I admit the current metacrisis was wreaking some havoc until I decided to shift gears and be more active in addressing it (both the worldâ€™s problems and my own). I have a good support network. I have been doing my work independently and with a therapist and other healers for decades, and Iâ€™ve made a lot of progress, perhaps beyond the range of what is normal. I think almost everyone would benefit from having a therapist or expanded care team. Thankfully, Iâ€™m mostly on the other side of past trauma and itâ€™s rare that occasional remnants come up now, and they are easily cleared. I have become far more resilient and joyful. So, I donâ€™t think it would be an issue in a relationship, but I wanted you to know, because it also speaks to my approach to difficult life situations and ability to resolve them well.
      * Speed shifts: I can move slowly or quickly, depending on the circumstances. I will spend hours and hours researching and considering all the options. But when I decide itâ€™s go-time, things can happen very quickly. It may look sudden, but it will generally be well-planned in advance over weeks or months, even years. These speed shifts can be disorienting if youâ€™re someone who prefers an orderly life that rarely changs. 


Languages 
I like languages. I just like to swim around, enjoying the SprachgefÃ¼hl, so Iâ€™m not fluent in most.
      * English - fluent
      * Spanish - nearly fluent
      * Bikol - moderately proficient
      * Tagalog - very basic
      * Bahasa - a little - I can sing a song!
      * German - 1 year in college
      * French - a bit, from watching movies
      * Korean - many basic phrases, from watching k-dramas
      * Japanese - a smidgeon
      * Mandarin - a teensy bit, mostly tai chi terms


My Professional World: 
My professional reality is fairly mundane but kinda neat â€“ Iâ€™m a middle manager of staff and operations for various humanitarian STEM projects and organizations, national and multinational. I got my start in this area as an executive assistant, where my skills often led to increasing management of operations and programs. Some have included things like green chemistry, next generation computing, non-linear electro-optics, biotechnology, sustainable agriculture, biofortification, genomics, space, medicine, and AI. I like the big picture. I also like details. Iâ€™ve worked in the non-profit, academic, and philanthropic sectors, and on public-private partnerships. Iâ€™ve co-managed a portfolio of international projects aimed at alleviating large scale poverty, the effects of climate change, and deaths from micronutrient deficiencies in the Global South. These days my job is smaller and more local, more routine and simple, which leaves me more time for hobbies, spiritual practices, and relationships. 


More pictures:


  

At my favorite tai chi event.
  

At Fuego volcano, Guatemala, Feb. 2024. Itâ€™s currently erupting!

Contact Info
You can email me at serenelotus75 [ a t ] gmail [ d o t ] com. Please tell me about yourself, what youâ€™re looking for, and where you think we might (or might not) align for dating. Or just say hi if youâ€™re curious about anything here. Feel free to send me your date-me doc link if you have one. Thanks, I look forward to connecting!


And if Iâ€™m not your cup of tea, but you know someone who might be, please feel free to share this document with them. All the best, and I hope you have a wonderful life!

profileDetails.fullText:
ï»¿Just a world traveler looking for a meaningful relationship
The Basics
Age: 43


Gender: Male


Orientation: Straight


Height: 6'2"


Ethnicity: South Asian


Location: Berkeley, California


Occupation: Principal Product Manager for Accessibility at an e-commerce company


Relationship Status: Divorced


Languages: English, Telugu (native), Hindi, Kannada, basic Spanish, basic Thai
Photos
 Kiran and India in Times Square. Kiran is a South Asian man with medium brown skin and close cut black hair. He wears a long sleeved button up collared shirt and dark jeans with Hokas. India is a golden retriever. He wears a guide dog harness and sits beside Kiran.  
    Kiran and India in front of a brick building. Kiran wears a burgundy polo and jeans with Hokas. He smiles broadly toward the camera. India leans against Kiran's leg.      Kiran and India in front of the Ed Sullivan Theatre, having just attended the taping of the Late Show with Stephen Colbert.  
Journey So Far
Hello world! - I was born in India, spent a bunch of years in the UK, and now call Berkeley home with my golden retriever guide dog, India. I travel to Seattle pretty regularly for work (1-2 weeks monthly), and through a mix of work and personal adventures, I've been fortunate enough to explore more than 30 countries over the years.


I work as a Principal Product Manager for Accessibility at a large e-commerce company, making sure everyone can shop online regardless of ability. I did similar work at other big tech companies. Having access to tech changed my life massively as a blind person, so I'm pretty passionate about making that happen for others too.


I've been blind since birth, and it's just one part of who I am. I've figured out how to adapt and be independent - honestly, it's made my life an adventure. By the way, I did not name my guide dog â€œIndiaâ€ for my country of birth. It was just a coincidence. Iâ€™ll tell you the story when we talk! If you're curious about how blind folks navigate technology or daily life, don't hesitate to ask. Or check out "The Tommy Edison Experience" on YouTube -  that guy is hilarious.
Passions & Interests
Music: I'll listen to almost anything with a good beat - Bollywood, reggae, Irish folk, Ed Sheeran (current favorite), Indian and western classical stuff... just please don't make me sit through heavy metal! Oh, and I just sing a lot, at home, in the shower or when the mood strikes me.
Reading: Total bookworm here. Growing up blind in India meant limited access to books, so now I'm making up for lost time. Huge Harry Potter fan, and currently obsessed with epic fantasies like Game of Thrones and anything by Brandon Sanderson. Sometimes I need a mental break and switch to something funny.
Trains & Travel: Ok, I'll admit it - I'm a complete train nerd. Building an N-scale model railroad layout with a friend's help, and even treated myself to a sleeper cabin on the California Zephyr for my 40th birthday. I went for the experience but I was reliably informed by fellow passengers that the views of the rockies are amazing! 




Work in progress of a railroad tunnel through a rock cliff. Model of a red rock cliff on a table in a garage. The strata is visible through horizontal divots.  Train tracks come out of the tunnel on  both the right and the left.     A train with a locomotive and two cars emerges from the tunnel portal which is made of card stock. The tunnel  portal is flat and still under construction. 


 A back view of the red rock cliff with train tracks extending to the right. The tracks bend back in a horseshoe. Green hills are visible on the other side of the table.  

  
I've been lucky enough to visit some incredible places - getting lost in Marrakech's medina with all its amazing smells and sounds, exploring the ancient temples at Angkor Wat, finally walking through Istanbul's Grand Bazaar after reading about it for years. Travel bucket list still includes Yellowstone, Caribbean islands, South America, and Australia/New Zealand. Oh, and a proper American road trip!




 Kiran and India before the Napa Valley Wine Train. 
     Kiran stands in front of the Galata tower in Istanbul, Turkey. 


 Kiran on boat. 



 Kiran sits in a helicopter pilot seat. He grins as he fiddles with the controls.  
     Kiran wades in calf-deep clear water before a small waterfall.    


Neighborhood Explorer: I'm big on exploring neighborhoods on foot - whether it's discovering hidden food gems in the bay area or wandering a new city. Did a full-day food walking tour in Istanbul once, sampling street food along the way - absolute heaven! Closer to home, I also love things like hiking the Bay Trail or spending a day exploring a new spot like Angel Island.
Food: Serious weak spot for good food - especially anything with creative spices. Thai cuisine is probably my favorite, but I'm game to try most things. Not really into bland food (British years taught me what that's like).
Current Projects: Learning conversational Spanish (hope it goes better than my failed piano experiment!). My native language is an Indian language called Telugu, and I also speak two other Indian languages, Hindi and Kannada fairly well. Can order food in very basic Thai - useful skill when you love Thai food as much as I do!
My Approach to Life
I'm definitely on the introverted side, but a good listener. Happy to chat about anything interesting but equally comfortable with quiet moments - not every silence needs to be filled, right?
Friends would describe me as loyal, curious about everything, and open-minded. I try not to judge others - we've all got our own paths.
I serve on the Board of Trustees for a national blindness non-profit, which feels like a way to give back. Sometimes I do podcasts and write blog posts about blindness awareness. Not trying to change the world single-handedly, but if I can help shift perspectives a bit, that's something.
"Differences of habit and language are nothing at all if our aims are identical and our hearts are open." - Dumbledore said it better than I could!
What I'm Looking For
Looking for something real and lasting. I want to find someone who's as curious about the world as I am - someone open-minded, kind, and who finds good conversation as enjoyable as comfortable silence.
Want a partner who's up for adventures, both local (Bay Area has some great spots to discover) and eventually international when schedules allow. I travel for work pretty regularly, but I'm committed to building something solid with the right person.
I'm a firm believer that relationships should expand our worlds, not shrink them. I'm hoping to find a partner to build a life with.
Deal-Breakers
â€¢ No smokers or heavy drugs 
â€¢ No judgmental or conservative people


Communication & Dating Style
I'd rather meet in person after establishing some basic compatibility - that's when you really know if there's a connection. I'm pretty straightforward, and appreciate the same in my partner.
Long-Term Vision
I don't have children and have made the personal decision not to have them in the future. I respect others' choices regarding parenthood and am looking for someone with similar life goals.


I've built a good life in the Bay Area but would consider relocating for the right relationship. Looking for a partnership where we both have room to grow individually while building something meaningful together.
 
So much world still to explore, so many experiences to share. Hope our paths cross soon!
Get in Touch
If something here resonated with you, reach out through this form, or shoot me a DM on Instagram or email me at kirankaja12@gmail.com.


Updated March 2025

ï»¿Hey! Iâ€™m Abe, and I thought Iâ€™d share a bit about myself, in case I sound like the sort of person youâ€™d like to date.


  



Some things I like to do:
* Theater. Iâ€™ve been acting since preschool, and itâ€™s my biggest hobby. I like everything from Shakespeare[1] to Rocky Horror[2], and I try to be in at least a couple community theater productions a year.
* Engineering. Yes, my day job is as a software engineer, but thereâ€™s so much to engineering besides software. I have hobby projects in everything from electronics to architecture, and I try to apply an engineering mentality to a lot of everyday problem-solving.
* Games. I play Dungeons & Dragons (usually running the game) and other tabletop roleplaying games, as well as board & card games such as Magic: the Gathering. I had a chess phase in middle school but was never very good at it.
* Bicycling. I bike as a means of transportation, not so much as a sport, but I do enjoy it, and avoiding dependence on cars is important to me.
* Crafts & home improvements. Iâ€™ve built a few pieces of furniture for myself, and done a number of repairs and upgrades around my house. I still contract out the big stuff, but I like having the option of doing things myself.
* Reading. While the internet has somewhat supplanted physical books for me, I still consider myself an avid reader, mostly of fantasy and sci-fi. My preference is for optimistic and/or silly stories over the dark & gritty style that seems to dominate these days, so it should come as no surprise that Terry Pratchettâ€™s Discworld is my favorite series.
* And much more. I can find something to enjoy in practically any creative activity, from linguistics to cooking to politics. A couple of the skills Iâ€™m currently trying to learn are singing and videography.


  
[3]


Basic biographical details:
* 29 years old â– male (albeit somewhat gender-apathetic) â– primarily attracted to women â– single â– open to mono- or polyamorous relationships, or just new friends â– 6 ft tall (1.82 m) â– vegetarian â– not religious â– doesnâ€™t smoke, drink alcohol, or do any other recreational drugs â– fully vaccinated â– night owl
* I live alone in Richmond, California (in the East Bay, just north of Berkeley). Not looking to move any time soon, but I might be open to having you move in if we get along well enough.
* I work full-time as a software engineer at an aerospace startup, Astranis Space Technologies. We make communications satellites to bring internet access to underserved areas (and we might also be building the next Global Positioning Satellite constellation).
* I grew up in Santa Cruz, but have also lived in Seattle, Nijmegen, and Santa Barbara.
* I have Bachelorâ€™s and Masterâ€™s degrees in computer science from UC Santa Barbara (College of Creative Studies).
* I usually vote Democratic, and consider my politics to be mostly progressive, though with some libertarian leanings.
* I donâ€™t currently have any pets, though I love them. My family had cats growing upâ€”I am slightly allergic to them, but that wonâ€™t stop me. Iâ€™d love to meet any pets you have.
* Iâ€™m autistic.[4] I got a diagnosis a few years ago, though in retrospect it should have been obvious.


  



What Iâ€™m looking for in a relationship:
* Fun conversations. Iâ€™ve got a lot of things I want to talk about, from interesting things Iâ€™ve learned to projects Iâ€™m working on to fundamental philosophical questions, but even better is to sit back and listen as you share something youâ€™re passionate about.
* Physical intimacy. This doesnâ€™t have to mean sex (though thatâ€™s great too), but I want to cuddle, to hug, to hold hands. Even better if you initiate.
* Shared activities. We could build something together, go on a bike ride or a hike, or just stay in and watch a movie. Lots of things are more fun as a couple, and itâ€™s easier to go through with something high-effort but rewarding if youâ€™re doing it with someone else.
* Stability. Knowing that we can depend on each other, and that weâ€™ll be there for one another. I donâ€™t want either of us to doubt how the other feels.
* I might be open to having kids, with the right person, but Iâ€™d be perfectly fine without as well.


  



Some of my values:
* Curiosity. Each new task is an opportunity to learn something. A surface-level understanding, like one might get from Wikipedia, is enough for a casual interest, but when something grabs my attention I want to get into as much detail as possible.
* Charity. I havenâ€™t formally taken the Giving What I Can pledge, but I do donate 10% of my gross earned income each year to effective charities (currently just Givewell).
* Preparedness. My friends turn to me when they need a phone charger, a bandage, or a bobby pin. Iâ€™ve taken Wilderness First Aid training, keep a deep pantry, and motivate myself to exercise with the idea that Iâ€™ll need to be fit in an emergency.
* Humor. It can take me a while to warm up enough to someone to make jokes around them, but once I do, Iâ€™m sure I can crack you up.
* Predictability. While Iâ€™m definitely open to new experiences, I find it much easier to enjoy them if Iâ€™ve had a chance to plan and research in advance. Surprises are stressful.
* Communication. Yes, itâ€™s a clicheÌ, but I really value being explicit in what you want. Iâ€™m not always great at picking up on social cues, so please tell me directly, and Iâ€™ll try to do the same for you.
* Kindness. There are a lot of awful things in this world, but we should never be them. I strive to see the best in everyone, to never raise my voice in anger, and to genuinely care about people.


  



Reach out
If you think we might be a good fit, or just want to chat, text me at (831) 419-9368 or email me at abe.karplus@gmail.com. I hope to hear from you soon!


Frequently Asked Questions[5]
* Q: Is there a spot open in your D&D group?
A: Yes, and if youâ€™re interested (and interesting) enough, it might be yours.
* Q: Whatâ€™s your personality type / star sign / Hogwarts house?
A: I donâ€™t put much stock in any of these, but INTP / Pisces / mostly Ravenclaw but some Hufflepuff.
* Q: You havenâ€™t said much about the sort of person youâ€™re looking for. Why not?
A: I think I could be compatible with a wide range of people, and I donâ€™t want someone wonderful to exclude themself just because they donâ€™t exactly match whatever description I gave.
* Q: Whatâ€™s your favorite Shakespeare play?

ï»¿In as many words


To love and be loved.


What I'm looking for


A deeper understanding and a genuine human connection. 


A relationship which should last a lifetime, and children, who I would like to see grow old.


A bit about me


I've probably done all of my imbibing, but when I do, I tend to have a cigarette. I don't do drugs. I like walking and running, and I'm thankful for my health. I can drive, but don't. I'll be moving into a home I'll actually own sometime in the future.


I'm learning to play the piano and hope to become quite proficient at it. I cook a lot, and don't mind vegetables in the slightest. I'm fascinated by physics, yet barely understand. I believe consciousness is a lot like a colour - entirely subjective.


Can't survive without music: Floating Points, RÃ³isÃ­n Murphy, Daniel Avery, HAIM, Kelly Lee Owens, HAAi, Ezra Collective, Lee Bong Geun, Mozart.


Reading: Tom Robbins, David Mitchell, Iain Reid, Phillip K. Dick, Cixin Liu, Haruki Murakami.


Film: Wes Anderson. And his complementary polar, Roy Andersson. Luc Besson, Guillermo del Toro, Coen brothers.


TV: Mad Men, The Office (only seen American), The Good Place, Gogglebox, Big Brother.


What I'm looking for


A woman of the world. Who has a real flair - instruments, languages, knowledge, conversation. Who blossoms rather shies away. An assuredness in herself - and I certainly don't want to be in competition! I'd prefer it if we talked with one another, and that we did this more than we talked about one another.


A lot more important than all of that, is a load of love and care.


I haven't exactly had an easy time in this world. I wouldn't want to dwell, but I've missed a lot of the joy and happiness. So to be reminded of such is a real treasure for me.


A bit more about me


I find it difficult to do some of the social aspects - which everyone else seems to be able to do - such as, to keep on top/point with the collective discussion; or find the relative clause with the fulcrum in a conversation. I'd probably be a bit better at it if there weren't the games, though. I haven't been diagnosed with autism.


I'm a bit of a realist, swaying towards the negative, but idealistic. â€” An empire is only in a mind! â€” A pensive deliberator, holistic narrator, where the only aim is to make sense and better understand. Physics is literally everythingâ€¦


The funniest part about physics is that it's not magic.


I'm not that serious! I flunk every test, simply because I canâ€¦ If I'm being told, I need to askâ€¦ I'm about as competitive as a wet sock... 


I hate conflict, but, even still, I could argue until the end of time - I just don't see the point! I don't hold any deep-seated beliefs - about this, or that. I think it's healthy to formulate an opinion, and especially, to care. I'm tired by the general discourse. Politics is literally everythingâ€¦


Only when humankind brings to an end the endeavour for prosperity, and instead works for the good of humanity, shall we truly prosper and realise wealth.


Or, as I see it, today...


When everyone is fooling everyone, everyone is a fool.


Dreams and aspirations


A job is a job for me. When I dream about my ideal home, it'd be supportive and positive. Lots of time for one another.


A relationship needs to be tender. I have endless patience, care and concern for the right woman.


A side note


We are no more intelligent than, even our earliest ancestors, we simply know more. Our evolution benefits from cooperation, as much as competition, if not more so by cooperation.


I feel, if you spend enough time with a person, you get to know one another, becoming forgiving, inclined, adaptable, agreeable, aligned and assured by them. You grow around one another, in any relationship, community, team, job and life. I'd only hope that we grow together.

I completed a relationship workshop that resulted in clarity about what I'm curious/interested (but not in any way expecting) to experience in an anchor romantic partnership. I'll list below some of that clarity; however, due to some feedback I received from a couple female friends, I've now updated this intro paragraph to make sure nobody reads the below as a list of requirements or expectations of a potential partner (which it is definitely not). Please consider the below as predilections and preferences, rather than a checklist of must-haves!
A) Acceptance of my non-monogamy.
For me to feel like I fully belong in the relationship, I've learned it's critical that my partner openly accepts me having multiple simultaneous romantic relationships, and that I retain the autonomy to pursue new ones.
B) Attraction/chemistry.
I am huge into touch, value sleeping together (in the literal sense), and love doing erotic stuff.
C) Perception that we're close peers.
This one took a lot of work to develop/unwind/discover in the workshop, and though I've learned it's important for me I'm still not yet sure why. In any case, what does "close peers" mean for me? Here's my best articulation, in five points; many of the examples derive from experiences in my own life and illustrate similar life experiences or attributes I seek in a partner.
"Close peer" #1: Overachiever. Doesn't much matter in what domain - maybe you're an elite gamer, or excel in fitness classes, or a director where you work, or finished your doctorate while founding a company, or pioneered a popular new form of tarot card therapy (yes I've encountered that latter ðŸ¤£).
"Close peer" #2: Leader. This might look like you teaching the class, running the workshop, organizing the campaign, driving the process change. Or that you lead by following, e.g. influencing others to put a full effort into the workout, modeling an innovative collaborative learning approach in the classroom that other students adopt, taking the meditation lesson to heart, signing the Giving Pledge and posting it in your house for others to follow.
"Close peer" #3: Wild. The freedom and power that comes from intentionally breaking a significant social rule, then thriving afterward. Perhaps you left a religion, risked your education by standing up for something unpopular, exited monogamy, or something comparably high-stakes that risked enduring family or social rejection or job loss.
"Close peer" #4: Seasoned. The maturity that comes from enduring a few hard knocks. Maybe you grew up in a household that lacked food security, or your baby died, or you weathered a disability you found difficult, or a parent neglected you.
"Close peer" #5: Mentally healthy. You regularly have more spoons than you need to make it through the day, and are more often than not positive and open and emotionally available.
-Someone recently asked me to describe "my tribe." I haven't found mine yet: but an overachieving altruist that wants to overachievingly altruist a bit harder as a result of their primary relationship, sounds like a kindred spirit to me.
Expectations
-I've learned that I expect roughly equal participation when it comes to the work of initiating, planning, and organizing. That means voicing the time and place and activity of proposed dates, initiating touch, proposing dinner plans, etc. should be shared roughly equally (rather than the male doing the disproportionate labor in these areas, as is the norm in heterosexual dating). This also applies to the vulnerable work of initiating the relationship conversations that are needed for a healthy relationship.
-I've also learned that my communication style merits calling out, since I have a particular approach that I've found perturbs some, while prompting others to offer kudos. My approach is this: I try to match the communication mode to the importance of the subject. To illustrate, let's say you're texting me with concerns about where we ate dinner last night. I will try to elevate the mode of communication to something real-time such as a phone call, video chat, or in-person discussion. I might even (gasp!) call you in response to your text.
In general, the more that feelings are involved or the stakes are high, the more I'll advocate to elevate the mode of communication (text < call < vid chat < in person). My reasoning is: the communication modes higher up the chain offer richer understanding since they include some or all of tone, pace, the opportunity to clarify, more words, pauses (and their absence), facial cues, and the accountability of a real-time conversation. This means fewer assumptions and more information, which I believe improves the odds of the desired twins of communication: (1) understanding and (2) being understood.
The downside is this approach requires hopping on a call, which some find less comfortable than texting, and can require a modicum of scheduling or driving to the partner, which texting doesn't. Know that for subjects like relationship status and where concerns are involved, I expect the conversation to be real-time, and I will engage using that mode where feasible.

Business ideas, people and relationships, ways to improve the NHS, why my cat behaves the way she does, what a conversation meant several years ago, whether we can have a viable economy based on currency that has another dimension of value attached to it, about meditation and yoga practices, about the nature of birth and death, how people grow and develop, about why my circuit breaker tripped for several days but is now back up and working perfectly fine, if a curry sauce filled tofu ball would be good bit of food, â€¦
   * Iâ€™d say Iâ€™m quite spiritual but not in the usual sense of the word. Iâ€™m highly logical with an open mind. I donâ€™t have beliefs. Iâ€™m purely in this life, with this body, with very limited perception of reality. But it is growing and I leave the door open.


  



Values
   * Open-mindedness - to me this means not being bought into anything. Staying open to being shown something new or contrary to current perspective.
   * Continuing to grow in awareness
   * Moving towards doing whatâ€™s more right and relevant for the world - this is not to say do not respect personal wants, but just recognising that personal desires tend to be formed by the world we reside in and they are highly transient - and it relates to the point above. With growing awareness I recognise that my desires are a consequence of my physiology, emotions, and memories - and as I become more conscious in my actions then the interactions of those elements also change. So, my desires change when my consciousness changes. Moving towards choice of desire from compulsive desires.
   * Rightness is debatable
   * Authenticity - I do feel that everyone is already authentic, there is nothing about a being that isnâ€™t - your actions and thoughts are not someone else's. I mean in the sense that we move towards growing awareness and express ourselves by our choice rather than by our compulsions.




What I want in a relationship


To have a companion to travel through life with.


Someone to share with
   * Food - I enjoy eating together, tasting new dishes (especially desserts )
   * Maybe some hobbies and projects - but not a dealbreaker
   * A home
   * Ideas and thoughts
   * What else?


Someone to learn from and learn with.
   * Intellectual curiosity - talking about concepts, situations, the future, history and bouncing ideas feels important to me.
   * A drop of spiritual curiosity - some amount of thirst to know more of life, consciousness and what we/I donâ€™t know.


Someone who really wants me.


Someone I really want to be with.


Hopefully, someone to have children with. So ideally aged between 25 and 35. But Iâ€™m not going to be strict on this - itâ€™s just what seems to make sense given that desire.
But with that said, Iâ€™d rather live a happy life than have kids at great cost to wellbeing.


Physical, emotional, and sexual intimacy.


The utmost mutual trust that weâ€™re in this together. Being on the same team.


Calling out bullshit and being able to step in when needed. Not letting undesirable things just happen without being addressed. Again, same team - doing this together.




Qualities that I find attractive in a partner


   * Feminine confidence
   * Gentle temperament but not meekness
   * Able to go with the flow as well as being adamant when needed
   * A curiosity for life's mysteries
   * Wittiness
   * Intellectual intelligence to an extent
   * Low maintenance and easy going nature - but still with a bit of fire
   * Straightforwardness
   * Adaptability (I may be projecting a bit here)
   * Groundedness




Some boundaries


Long distance relationship - itâ€™s a no for me. A LTR doesnâ€™t feel real to me and seems like a dream life not real life. I know it can work for many people, but I donâ€™t feel this is the situation Iâ€™d thrive in.
Perhaps later on if there needs to be some distance due to short term work, looking after parents, etc then thatâ€™s fine - just doesnâ€™t seem right to begin with.


I like communication to be straightforward with no game playing. Donâ€™t make it harder than it needs to be. I truly feel there are much better ways to use our energy than playing around with each other.










What we could have together
   * A warm loving home and family where we nurture each other.
   * Deep mutual trust that we are here for each other.
   * Great intimacy - physically, emotionally, sexually, and any other way that comes to mind.
   * Financial security and freedom - we can work on this together. So that we can pursue things other than careers and money motivated endeavours - do things that are more alive.
   * Support each other in our pursuits. Even have some things that we pursue together.
   * Have kids and grow into wonderful guides for them as they grow.
   * Each of us puts effort into being the best for the other - then there will be no getting bored, things going stale, the flame dying out. Selfishly selfless route to endless passion and energy.
   * Share in the responsibilities of life and home. As equally as possible. Recognising that it doesnâ€™t necessarily mean the physical actions are completely equal. But we do whatâ€™s needed.
   * A really fun time and fun life!




  







With all that said, that is my brain dump for now.


Letâ€™s meet!


jyue87 [at] gmail [dot] com

Obligatory Headshot
Hi there! I'm on the market, and if you're looking at this, then I guess you are too. This should help us navigate those awkward first steps.
I'm looking for someone to live and love with long-term while we both support each other's goals. I've never been married and while I'd be happy with a lifetime partner, I don't know that marriage itself is the right setup for me. That said, I have been in a 5+ year relationship. In the meantime, let's just be nice to each other and test our compatibility. We can see if there's an intersect in what we're looking for and do what seems right in the meantime.
My ideal partner has obsessions and can't help but share them. She has clear goals and a plan to achieve them, even if they're hard as hell. (I'm talking to you, ambitious women other guys are afraid of.) She takes care of herself now, knowing our bodies get harder to maintain as we age. Also, no kids, religion, or perpetuating animal suffering through food choices. She wants to make a positive mark on the world.
I take on challenging goals. I'm mostly through the manuscript of a nonfiction book on a technical topic. I've published in both academic journals and popular media. I've also grown two nonprofits from scratch. I set up the org and funding mechanism that helped a long-active male contraceptive to a Phase I human clinical trial. I also facilitated campaigns to get a better voting method implemented in two cities, which had never been used in government elections before. I've raised millions of dollars for causes I care about. I enjoy being active and have a ton of different hobbies.
Location-wise, I can live anywhere for my work and recently chose Philadelphia after referencing a simple heat table I put together factoring in cost of living, walkability, transit, and bikability. I actively do not like cars and choose not to own one. I do have a license and can drive though. I have to do this visiting Kentucky during the holidays.
Other randomness. I care about financial independence. I budget for charitable giving and give publicly. I also love science and am rather methodical at most things I try my hand at. If youâ€™re as obsessed with learning, weâ€™ll probably get along great. Also, I try my best for clarity on all this, but if you're still nicking a particular box and things look otherwise good, I'd still be up for us talking and checking things out.

I am 23, I live in Oxford, studied in my native Australia, and grew up mainly in India.[1] I feel moved by the plight of current people and non-human animals, but also find persuasive the basic longtermist argument that the future is big and important and changeable. So for now I am trying to help make the transition to AGI go well.
You can see some things about me on various places online, including the EA Forum, LinkedIn, Goodreads, Google Scholar, and my Substack subscriptions.
That is fairly cold and impersonal; it is perhaps more fun and interesting to get to know each other by talking. But for now, here are some less work-y things about me:
* I like to read, play board games and ~any sport, hike and camp, talk about philosophy and physics and photosynthesis and occasionally non-alliterating things.
* I am very honest and value open, frank, fairly direct communication with others. I tend to ask quite a few questions, mainly because I am curious to learn about other peopleâ€™s experiences and ideas!
* I am not very artsy; beyond the occasional poem (e.g. here, here), and some elegant mathematising if that counts, my creative output is meagre.
* I have rather little familiarity with pop culture and I mostly do not regret this. But it means I wouldnâ€™t be a very good conversationalist on such things.

About you
Apart from demographic things (I have only ever been attracted to women, this seems very unlikely to change; being a somewhat similar age/life stage is helpful) and unsurprising things (oneâ€™s partner being kind and clever and caring and calm and courageous is always nice) I would like to be with someone who is:

I think I would struggle to deeply empathise with and respect someone who had a more blasÃ© attitude to improving the world. It seems less important what exactly you care about and want to work on.[3]
* Intellectually curious - talking about ideas is quite important to me, and it would be hard to spend lots of quality time with someone who isnâ€™t interested in ideas. But what you study/studied, who your favourite philosophers are, what your favourite theorem is etc is less important.
Beyond that, of course, it would be nice if we enjoyed some of the same activities, but I feel like that is more malleable.
It would clearly be nice to live near each other, but I am open to exploring a relationship with someone who currently lives far away.[4]
I am open to ~any preference on whether to have kids, I have quite mixed thoughts.[5]

* My face is not very expressive, and I seem much colder than I actually am to a lot of people. I convey strong emotion much more with verbal explanation than with any visual cue.
* The places Iâ€™ve lived are not bustling with like-minded people.

* Ideally looking for a monogamous relationship, but open to casual dating
* Want children in 5-15 years, but I donâ€™t think this is a dealbreaker
* Muscular build, lean but not shredded
* Atheist
* 27 years old, British
* Non-smoker, rarely drink but not teetotal
* First-class Chemistry degree
* Vegan
* ~Â£50k salary, own a flat in Glasgow with a small mortgage

* Main love language is physical touch, followed by quality time  


Work life
Iâ€™ve decided against publishing this on the Internet. Feel free to enquire. 
  

Character traits
   * Discipline, drive, and executive function
   * Very low in neuroticism and anxiety, with a stable mood (Iâ€™ve got graphs lol)
   * When Iâ€™m sad, I solve this through reflection and talking about it; â€œcheering me upâ€ isnâ€™t a thing
   * Regrettably low in some kinds of curiosity
   * Direct style of communication  
   * Hard to offend
   * Aside from a few skeletal anomalies that havenâ€™t meaningfully limited me, I have excellent health (as do most of my family)
   * Probably too invested in some kind of general protagonist identity, and working on being warmer and more human
   * I very much have â€œcognitive empathyâ€; I care about people/things, but donâ€™t feel their emotions with them.
   * Iâ€™m becoming more disagreeable and willing to challenge people as I age. Iâ€™d like to believe I keep this constructive and make sure not to leave others feeling attacked. If your tortilla policy is mental, or I think a key part of your philosophy is wrong, youâ€™ll hear about it. 


Daily routines
      * I am more of a morning person; staying up late into the night without a good reason is not a thing for me
      * I reach full alertness and energy exactly 20 minutes after getting up

THE KNOCKOFF POEM


 


Somebody posted on Instagram or Facebook -- or was it Twitter?


 


This picture of a Nerf football.


Something funny was written -- a witticism about the spongy ball being a dogâ€™s delight.


But I was fixed on that foam football,


Unlocking a surprising cache of memory.


 


I donâ€™t think my childhood ever saw a real Nerf football.


Just a cheaper, if thatâ€™s possible, knockoff.


There was a pink plastic football


I remember.


A knockoff of a knockoff, a buying pattern that runs through my early family experience.


 


Fake Rubikâ€™s cubes and triangles,


Loose and adorned with failing stickers,


eventually plocked apart by my too-curious brother.


 


We didnâ€™t get Pong until Dad 


happened by a yard sale.


This was real Atari -- but so many years too late.


 


The Pong battles burned lines


in the screen of our portable black and white TV,


another knockoff,


until you couldnâ€™t watch any shows â€“ via a knockoff antenna -- without more imagination than you wanted to exert.


My brother eventually took the TV apart as well.


 


Knockoffs. 


It was the age of brand names


and we were having none of it 


in our recession-pocked existence on the farm.


 


The air was real.


The vegetables.


The fruit.


The eggs.


The barn.


And the animals,


all named,


our own branding scheme,


I suppose.


We werenâ€™t focus-group savvy about it.


More Captain Obvious.


A rust-colored horse called Cinnamon, 


her gray sister, Pepper,


the jet-black brother Midnight.


 


We named a cow Hamburger, 


bringing to mind my brother brightly chirping 


over the Salisbury steak I hated:


Who are we eating tonight?


 


All of this streaming


from a photo on my phone.


 


More than tackle football
during fifth-grade recess
with real Nerf football


 


I grimace, but not


from this trip


to a memoryâ€™s lane


of pre-teen products and uses.


I wince with a wont


for a time when I engaged


more wholly in my life.


Actually.


Not virtually


or electro-socially.


That pink football was lost


in the open cesspool 


in the front yard,


a sewage maw in the earth,


covered by boards,


some broken, with gaps forming.


And there went the ball.


 


That pit was filled in


when the new septic came on.


It became second base of our


kickball field, marked by a lid 


from a can of knockoff paint.


 


Home was the front steps.


First was a pine tree,


third a boxelder.


None of which remain today. 


 


Once you hit a certain age, probably 13, 


you are constantly told


to not look back.


Forge ahead.


Donâ€™t rue.


As if simple acknowledgement


of a life lived


was some sign of malignant sorrow, 


or akin to sucking a finger for too long.


 


Should my memories


be buried under the sluice of time like that pink football?
Itâ€™s all been a setup, of course,


to the knockoff lives lived today.


Unengaged and not in any moment,


let alone â€œtheâ€ moment.


 


Iâ€™m going to stop feeling bad about my reminiscence.


Iâ€™ve abstained long enough.


I relish this spongy reminder


of youthful engagement.


 


Physical proofs fading,


all I have left is memory:


prodded by a photo


found on my handheld,


soul-sucking device.


 


A Nerf football.


Also handheld.


But, so unexpectedly,


soul nourishing.

Created Jan. 2025
  
  
  

  
  

  
  

Life is more vibrant when shared: Emotional reactions are heightened when another person is in the room. Experiences are richer when you see them through someone elseâ€™s eyes as well as your own. Ideas are enhanced when they volley between two brains. And we need companionship to feel safe and soothed. So Iâ€™m looking for someone(s), romantic or platonic, with whom I can share this brief and miraculous existence. 


Iâ€™m easily influenced by the mood and energy of those around me, so Iâ€™m looking for someone who brings out the person I want to be. If you are compassionate, curious, encouraging, extraverted (or at least prone to Doing Stuff), and enthusiastic, read on. 


Vision
In my ideal life, periods of fairly regimented, healthy routine are punctuated by wild adventures. 


During the week, and some weekend days, I anticipate following my morning routine (including meditation), going to work, going to the gym (I lift weights daily, even though Iâ€™m bad at it), and having a couple of remaining hours to engage in activities that are both self-improving and genuinely fun, as energy permits (at home, like reading, studying languages, or chatting, or out, like taking a dance class, seeing a play, or going for a hike). Iâ€™d love to share these activities with someone. Iâ€™m a fan of Cal Newportâ€™s philosophy and techniques for creating structure that allows for productivity without pushing oneself. I would like my home (whether rented or owned) to be attractive, neat, and quiet; I care about aesthetics, and Iâ€™m easily distracted by clutter or unpredictable interruptions. I enjoy cohabiting, but I donâ€™t want to be influenced by unhealthy habits like poor sleep or media addiction, so unless the cohabitant(s) is/are conscientious and wellness-oriented, Iâ€™d rather live alone. This routine is valuable to me not out of some kind of moralizing asceticismâ€”and in fact, I donâ€™t view it as asceticâ€”but because itâ€™s the structure and peace I need to do the kind of work that excites me while staying well and relaxed. 


But life is for the alive, my dear (as Mrs. Lovett would say), so weekends and vacations are for experiencing what the world has to offer. I easily feel delight and awe in the wacky things that man and nature have created, and Iâ€™m novelty-oriented, so Iâ€™m not all that particular about what I do for recreation. I am, however, especially interested in travel, as well as entertaining at home by hosting themed parties and game nights. Although during my daily life I prefer to be relatively frugal, I donâ€™t mind spending money on the experiences I value (and on maintaining my well-being), whether thatâ€™s play tickets or Michelin starred tasting menus. 


Do you see yourself as compatible with at least one of these elements of my vision? Iâ€™m open to a cohabiting partner, an adventure buddy, or both. Iâ€™m game for romantic or platonic â€¦ but it would be really neat to fall in limerence. 


In the interests of transparency, Iâ€™ll admit that my life currently doesnâ€™t reflect this vision as well as I would like. Even though I look reasonably successful on paper (e.g., have lots of grants and publications, worked at a â€œbig threeâ€ consulting firm, etc.), Iâ€™ve struggled to find my groove since the beginning of the pandemic, which coincided with me finishing my postdoc and starting my â€œreal grown-up job.â€ Health, relationships, and non-ideal housing have all been an impediment, and Iâ€™ve been experimenting to find out what works better. Some major changes are in the works for the next six months, including moving and launching the career that aligns with my strengths and passion. Itâ€™s perhaps immature to believe that a romantic relationship can â€œfixâ€ a person, but I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s quite what Iâ€™m looking for; I am hoping, though, that an infusion of new and positive energy, and a supporter of my routines, will serve as a nudge in the right direction. 


About me
I would describe myself as resourceful, curious, irreverent, passionate, and idealistic. Superpowers: Generating ideas, perspective-taking, offering reassurance, designing solutions, evaluating the trustworthiness of research evidence (i.e., detecting BS). Weaknesses: Attentional control, trusting my decisions/trusting the process, managing energy, patience, singing. 


Stats

Education: PhD
Age: 37
Gender: AFAB, nonbinary-ish

Relationship style: Prefer kitchen table poly

Religion: Respectful atheist with Buddhist sympathies 
Politics: Pragmatic, favoring left-leaning goals but not necessarily left-leaning means; â€œCanâ€™t-we-all-just-get-alongâ€-ism; â€œThey-should-put-me-in-chargeâ€-ism ðŸ™ƒ
Substances: No alcohol, tobacco, or cannabis (though I donâ€™t object if others use them wisely); rare psychedelics for therapeutic purposes

Beliefs and values
(I donâ€™t expect you to share all of these beliefs; diversity of thought is useful! Iâ€™m just offering them as information about me.)
* The world would be saved if everyone practiced perspective-taking and compassion and everyone made decisions using cost-effectiveness analysis with the best available evidence as inputs. (In other words, all you need is love and science.)
* Physicalism is true, or at least, thereâ€™s no reason to believe otherwise; everything is made of matter and there is probably no parallel spirit world or soulstuff. Spiritual practices and rituals, however, can be worthwhile. 
* Capitalism has pros and cons. Markets are magical mechanisms, and Iâ€™m skeptical that there are other ways of allocating resources that would be comparably effective, but Iâ€™d really like to see markets (and governments) totally redesigned in a way that incentivizes wellbeing-maximization rather than promoting insecurity-generating competition, concentration of wealth, pointless and addictive consumption, etc. I havenâ€™t formally studied econ or political science, so thatâ€™s kinda where my hopes end. I am curious about these topics, though. 
* Most forms of entertainment media and social media are bad for our brains and trick us into thinking theyâ€™re worthwhile, in an analogous process to that promoted by addictive substances. Theyâ€™re too stimulating and too instantly-gratifying. This is true of other products as well, like processed foods. 
* Science rules, but itâ€™s often performed suboptimally. Fixing this is my career missionâ€”one that Iâ€™ve thought about for years and have finally started to pursue. 
* Aside from physical pain/discomfort, insecurity (about status, lovability, etc.) is the core source of most suffering. If people felt â€œgood enoughâ€ and psychologically safe, theyâ€™d be much less defensive, more able to accept othersâ€™ perspectives, care for others, etc. In other words, feeling interpersonally secure is intrinsically as well as instrumentally good. 
* Emotion is good. Life should be interesting. I want to cry more and laugh more. 
* Itâ€™s fun to be critical, but itâ€™s also fun to appreciate mediocre art and suspend disbelief.
* Probably some other stuff, but youâ€™ve already spent long enough reading my stream-of-consciousness manifesto, so letâ€™s move on. 


Hobbies and interests
The items on this list range from â€œstuff I think about every dayâ€ to â€œstuff I do once a monthâ€ to â€œstuff I aspire to try.â€ 
* Metascience
* Psychology, economics, philosophy

* Psychedelics
* Buddhism, meditation; curious about relational meditation practices
* Lotsa other stuff tooâ€”teach me about your hobbies! 


About you 
Iâ€™ve already articulated much of what I want; hereâ€™s all of it in one place. Yes, I know these lists arenâ€™t grammatically parallel. Forgive me. 


Qualities Iâ€™m seeking: 
* Compassionate, warm, and encouraging
* Curious and intellectually engaged
* Extraverted and/or active; â€œyes andâ€ attitude
* Communicative about own mental state
* Has own hobbies and interests
* Has a vision/direction for life (does not need to be a traditional career), preferably one that includes reducing the worldâ€™s suffering
* Enthusiastic about at least some portion of my proposed lifestyle, or already practices it


Qualities about which I care less than most people:

* Body type (Iâ€™ve dated hefty bears and wispy dudes I could beat at arm wrestling)

* Religion (you do you, given a reasonable level of skepticism/critical thinking; I love ritual)

Dealbreakers: 
* Cynicism
* Frequent or persistent low mood/low energy
* Meanness or disdain towards neurodivergent people, trans people, sex workers, or fat people â€¦ actually, letâ€™s make that meanness or disdain towards anyone! 
* Dogmatic beliefs, especially political beliefs in the vein of â€œthe â€˜otherâ€™ is an unforgivable bad guyâ€

Next steps
If you think we might be a match, email me at my first name dot my last name (which is Bernecker) at the Google internet mail. (I hope thatâ€™s obfuscated enough to fool robots while remaining intelligible to humans.) Please tell me what youâ€™re seeking, highlight a few things in this doc that made you think weâ€™d be a good fit, and mention any concerns about our compatibility.

ï»¿Hi there,


Letâ€™s start with the basics: Iâ€™m Arun. 31 years old, living in India, and by day, Iâ€™m the person behind the Instagram posts and Facebook ads for a school. Itâ€™s a job that lets me play with colors, stories, and the occasional dad joke though Iâ€™m slowly learning to trade pixels for words. Not the flashy kind, but the ones that linger, like the last line of a poem you canâ€™t forget.


If I had to describe myself, Iâ€™d say Iâ€™m a lot like my favorite comfort food: dal rice. Simple, warm, maybe a little unassuming at first glance. But stick around, and youâ€™ll find tiny surprises a crackle of cumin, a hint of ginger the kind of details that make you smile when you notice them. Mornings here are slow, evenings quieter still. Youâ€™ll often find me tucked into a corner with a book, rewatching that scene in One Piece where Luffy sets fire to the World Governmentâ€™s flag (you know the one), or knitting a muffler Iâ€™ll probably gift to someone before winter ends.


Iâ€™ve never been the loudest voice in the room. Grief has a way of teaching you the weight of silence, and Iâ€™ve learned to carry mine gently. But if you let me, Iâ€™ll listen to your stories, your fears, the way you take your coffee. (Yes, Iâ€™ll remember it. Even if you donâ€™t.)


My heart lives in stories.


Haruki Murakamiâ€™s worlds, where loneliness feels like an old friend. The dog eared pages of library books, where strangers leave fragments of themselves in underlined sentences. Iâ€™m even writing my own novel In the Quiet of Words about two people who fall in love through notes tucked between chapters. Itâ€™s bittersweet, like most things I adore.


Anime? Oh, absolutely. Give me a character with scars and a stubborn heart (20th Century Boys, anyone?), and Iâ€™ll give you a 2 AM essay on why their journey matters. And donâ€™t get me started on Made in Abyss its beauty and brutality wreck me every time.


When Iâ€™m not lost in fiction, Iâ€™m knitting. It started as therapy, really. Just me, some yarn, and a podcast murmuring in the background. Now, every stitch feels like a prayer for peace, for patience, for the friend whoâ€™ll wear the lopsided scarf I made.


Oh, and I cook. Nothing fancy, just soul food. A good dal rice, shared under a ceiling fanâ€™s lazy whir, is my love language.


Work? Itâ€™s a dance of spreadsheets and creativity.


Iâ€™m building something meaningful at the school crafting stories that connect with parents, students, dreamers. Someday, Iâ€™d love to lead a tiny team of big hearted weirdos who believe marketing can be kind and clever.


But my secret ambition? To write. Not for clicks, but for the quiet hearts who find solace in sentences. My novelâ€™s a mosaic of all Iâ€™ve felt love that aches, loss that lingers, and the stubborn hope that broken things still glow.


What am I looking for?


You.


Someone who sees the world softly the way rain taps a rhythm on windows, how old Hindi comedies (Hera Pheri, hello!) can make you snort laugh even when the jokes shouldnâ€™t land. Someone whoâ€™s okay with slow dances, deep talks, and silences that donâ€™t need filling.


You donâ€™t need to love Murakami or anime (though Iâ€™ll geek out if you do). Just bring curiosity, kindness, and a heart that believes libraries are the closest thing to magic.


Random confessions:


I cried once while knitting. The â€œwhyâ€ is a story Iâ€™ll tell you over chai.


Iâ€™ll pack snacks for our trips sweet, salty, and a charger for your dying phone.


My idea of romance? Leaving a book on your desk because a paragraph made me think of you.


If any of this resonates, letâ€™s swap stories. Iâ€™ll bring the dal rice.


â€” Arun


(P.S. If you read this far, tell me your favorite comfort food. Iâ€™m taking notes.)

* Software engineer at big tech company. Rust dev, with interest in LLM interpretability and AVX-512. I love `vpternlog` and `vgf2p8affineqb`.
* Location: Vancouver WA/Portland Oregon, but long term flexible, preferably west coast

* Enjoys snuggles, long walks in the forest, and long intellectual discussions.


I grew up in a house with a few thousand books in a forest. My parents mostly home schooled me, and I read inordinate quantities of books growing up. Having spent the last ~decade of my life focused on career advancement and saving money, I am now in a position to turn my attention to the next few decades/remainder of my life.


I enjoy cooking, and will happily make you good food. While I am reluctant to be strictly vegan due to health concerns, I am happy to optimize in an animal suffering reducing direction.


I am interested in a long term monogom-ish relationship, but am poly compatible if needed. Given an interest in, and non-zero hope of, living to see the sun burn down, I am somewhat reluctant to commit to anything for the rest of my life, but for the right person, I would be happy to commit to stay together for the next 100 years.










Interested in raising children


Children are important. I think my parents did a good job of raising me, but I want to do even better. If we end up having children, I strongly want to be a ~full time parent for at least the first ~decade of my children's life. While I am undecided on exact optimal schooling arrangement, I do feel strongly that pure public school is significantly sub-optimal.

Problem statement
I decided to use one of the Engineering solution templates from Notion, so my problem is figuring out how to use this without making people think I need a group of overpaid college graduates to fix me.
But really, my goal is to find a loving, rewarding relationship with a female I am interested in and for whom I am willing to sacrifice the time necessary to build a relationship. Someone who is kind, intelligent, silly, curious, courageous, and empathetic. And very importantly, someone who is emotionally mature enough to realize the kind of work and sacrifices that a relationship entails.
I am pretty flexible about the actual location, since my job is usually remote. Buttt I am a sucker for good weather - Iâ€™ve lived in the Bay Area for most of my life and in Malaga, Spain for a little bit so I am not going to pretend that living in Norway would be perfect for me. But love transcends all, right? ðŸ˜›Â Iâ€™ll try to use some of the existing fields in this template that I find are surprisingly appropriate or just funny.
Goals
Ideally - find someone who is compatible with me in a relationship sense by showing them this document and some pictures of me, at which point they will fall hopelessly in love.
Non-goals
Meeting more guys. Just kidding! If you think we would be two cubes in an ice tray, regardless of what your gender is, then totally message me and we can haaanggg. See â€œImplementation and Rollout Planâ€ for contact details.
Proposed solution
Meet a lot more girls with the openness to a relationship or just a friendship depending on how we feel about each other. I see either as a win, but I want to be clear that my intention going into a meeting is 80% to date and 20% to be friends. To be clear, I love having a relationship that has the foundation of a friendship. But I am not sure how this is possible unless we read this doc, signed a binding contract to be friends, erased our memories, and then one day felt that we could be more.
I think itâ€™s easier going from â€œAh I donâ€™t see this working out as a relationship, but we can totally drink boba like every 5 weeksâ€ rather than â€œHey we drink boba like every 5 weeks, but I want to see you again tomorrow.â€
Interests and Hobbies
Programming - I am a software engineer who has worked for blockchain companies (trading and gaming-related) and I am extremely grateful that I truly enjoy my work! I love building things with an end customer in mind and I find it awesome that solving cool problems can make peoplesâ€™ lives better. Somehow, I think the universe was beautifully designed that way.
Math/Physics
I kind of have this weird liking for math competition problems and I think it is so beautiful how we can create abstractions to describe the physical world
I have explored ML, but I frankly donâ€™t really like things that are that much of a black box to the point where we are just working backwards to find the motivation from the implementation
I used to be really bad at physics in high school and kind of hated it, but in college I decided to try to do my best and I actually ended up really liking it and I was a teaching assistant for a couple of physics classes
Strategy Games
Really Like
Catan (I love the 1v1 version of Colonist, I was ranked Diamond two seasons ago and btw the username is from Looking for Alaska by John Green haha)

Hate

Losing (in honesty, I can get pretty competitive sometimes haha)

Rowing
Comedy
Improv (for me, humor compatibility in a relationship is huge and if I can do a bit with you, that is a huge plus)
Conan Oâ€™Brien <3
Values
Honesty
I am the kind of person who tries to say what is on his mind in a compassionate, caring way towards myself and others
I think short-term discomfort is worth long-term growth
I really resonate with the quote from the Kite Runner, â€œThat's the thing about people who mean everything they say.Â They think everyone else does too.â€ It just means to me that if we both trust ourselves to be honest, we can assume good intention and it just makes things soooooo much easier (and we can also move much faster haha!)
Gentleness/Kindness
I donâ€™t feel like a man needs to be â€œassertiveâ€ or â€œdominantâ€; I think being gentle and kind is strong in itâ€™s own way
I think being kind and loving and holding someoneâ€™s heart with care are so much more important and I want to be with someone who values the care I give to them
Fighting Well
I think in a relationship fights are inevitable, but I think healthy relationships fight well
Physical violence is not okay, as are demeaning comments
We try to argue our points to the best of our knowledge and acknowledge good points from the other side
We are both mentally healthy enough that we do our best to make it work but have the power to walk away at any time
Health
I have become much healthier over the last 7 or 8 years and I would love to meet someone who also cares about what they put in their body
I love to exercise on a regular basis, whether it is swimming, running, rowing, or playing soccer
I donâ€™t expect my partner to be interested in the same activities (I guess this goes for really everything Iâ€™ve said so far haha)
Also pretty into meditation, although my view on its importance has changed a lot over the past few years
Selfish Altruism with a Mix of Loving Without Expectation
I think it is important to figure out what brings you joy and how you can use that to bring joy to others
Bare altruism is rarely a good long-term goal - how many vegetarians/vegans have you met who did it for the sake of the world but gave up because of how futile they felt their attempts were in making a dent in the animal consumption problem?
For me, becoming almost fully vegetarian/vegan was a decision inspired by my getting healthier and looking better
But I think loving yourself allows you to love others best :); and loving without expectation is the best way to show up in life and in a relationship - that love doesnâ€™t have any promises; you just have to be grateful for every moment, and enjoy every single moment
Curiosity/Playfulness
I love being just fun and silly and weird and my humor can be dirty sometimes with people I feel comfortable with, and I hope to find someone I can play with for the rest of my life
I think that the universe is somehow inherently playful - it does without any purpose and it rewards joy and spreading happiness
I think everything is connected from chess to physics to swimming to flowers and I love to find and think about these connections
Belief/Confidence/Ambition
I truly believe that the universe works with you on goals you really believe in and that the universe responds when you ask it for something and put a full-hearted effort into it
I think working towards goals that ignite us is what we live for and itâ€™s important to me that my partner is decently ambitious as well
Physical Connection
Physical touch is one of my love languages, so I would ideally like to be with someone who also likes that :)
I think sex to me is a part of expressing love in a relationship, and while it shouldnâ€™t be at the forefront of whatâ€™s going on, I think itâ€™s important that there is good physical compatibility
I donâ€™t think about sex that much at all, unfortunately, so I can tend to be bad at initiating; however, this is something I am happy to work on
Pictures
And here are some (silly) pictures of me! I guess if I had to describe myself, I am a 5â€™ 10.5â€™â€™ guy who tends to be kind of skinnier/toned side. A lot of these are in Europe (I lived in Spain for a bit last year!) and I switch a lot between having and not having a beard, so Iâ€™ll include pictures of both ðŸ™‚

Hopefully, we can be very open with each other if we think things are working out. I am sometimes really good but otherwise hopelessly lost in reading signs from girls.
I also donâ€™t want to waste either of our time - I think a relationship is an opportunity cost and I hope that we are both gaining something from our time together to make up for it.

Haha, did you actually fall for this big pile of steaming â€¦? Okay sorry, like I said my humor can be a bit strange sometimes. Hopefully, you didnâ€™t actually stop reading. Like YO MAMMA IS SO FAT, THAT SHE GOES THROUGH A LUNAR CYCLE EVERY TIME SHE PIROUETTES. Who said my jokes were good?

CV/Resume
LinkedIn
Substack
Carson McNeil is a Neuroscientist, Data Scientist, Consultant, and Researcher specializing in medical imaging, neuroscience, and machine learning applications.
With a background in both computational neuroscience and software engineering, Carson has planned and executed on high-impact projects at Forest Neurotech, Verily Life Sciences, Google, and the
University of California, Berkeley. His work bridges cutting-edge machine vision and deep learning techniques with practical applications in health, such as the development of generative models for
digital pathology. Carson's work has spanned basic research in the cognitive neuroscience of human vision, the neuroscience of Buddhist meditative states,
and many practical applications of machine learning to diagnostic healthcare problems. His research is driven by a desire to improve human health, happiness, and flourishing, whether mental or physical.
He believes in driving forward practical technologies while sharing and publishing relevant scientific findings with the world.
Carson has a long-running interest in Mysticism, and believes that there
is not such a difference between the tools we think of as "therapeutic",
and millenia-old mystical traditions such as Buddhism and Daoism. A culture,
such as ours, which is overly materialistic and has lost touch with the subjective,
the natural, and the ritualistic, is at risk of collapsing under its own weight.
Carson hopes that his teaching, writing, and research will help bridge this divide,
and make esoteric mysticism more legible to the rationally-minded scientist.
We rarely hear the inner music, but we are all dancing to it nonetheless.
- Rumi
Please do reach out if you are interested in research collaboration, coaching, or consultation!
Research and Teaching
I have two Neuroscience degrees (Caltech BA 2013, UC Berkeley Masters 2019). I have also worked as a
researcher and Data Scientist at Google Machine Intelligence, YouTube, and Verily Life Sciences. My research interests span medical imaging, neuroscience, machine intelligence, and Dharma science.
Google Scholar profile
LinkedIn profile
Research Tools
Ultrasound Neuroimaging
At Forest Neurotech, we are developing a device that can image and modulate functional activity
in the human brain cheaply, portably, and minimally-invasively.
We hope this technology will be used to treat a wide range of conditions from
depression to addiction
,
as well as brain-machine interfacing
and neuroscience research.
Autofluorescence Microscopy
While at Verily, I worked on the
Virtual Stainer
project. We used generative learning to predict histological stains from autofluorescence scans of unstained tissue. See
(McNeil et al., 2024)
, in Modern Pathology, and other publications.
Medical Image Embedding
I worked on a project to use Masked-Siamese Networks to embed colonscopy videos in a semi-supervised way. See
(Shor, McNeil et al., 2024)
Functional Neuroanatomy
While at Berkeley, I was in the
Gallant Lab
within the Berkeley Artificial Intelligence Research org, working on fMRI research projects to model the human visual system.
Human Emotion
While at Google Machine Intelligence, I kicked off a collaboration between Google and Berkeley to study emotion in human faces using DNNs. 5 years later, this collaboration produced
(Cowen et al. 2021)
in Nature. I have an ongoing interest in emotion and mental health.
Drugs and the Brain
While at Berkeley, I taught the course
Drugs and the Brain
under
Prof. David Presti
. At Caltech, I taught a class of the same name under
Prof. Henry Lester
. Psychedelics, as a therepeutic, spiritual, and investigative tool remain of interest to me.
Creative Content
Scienctific work is creative work. But I have also produced a lot of more casual content.
Substack Essays
Medium Essays (will move to Substack)

YouTube Lectures
I have several long-form talks on psycho-spiritual frameworks on my
YouTube Channel
. These were given at a private event, and due to popular acclaim, I posted them online. Perhaps more on this theme will follow.
Essays
I write essays sometimes, which I post to my
Substack
. The topics range between philosophy, poetic, light research projects, and psychology. For example:
Polyamory doesn't Liberate; Monogamy doesn't Protect by Carson
Reflections and community quotes from a decade in the Bay Area dating landscape.
Read on Substack
Wedding Ritual Design for a Pluralistic Society by Carson
A recollection of, and guide to, hand-crafting a syncretic, modern, and personal wedding ceremony.
Read on Substack
Flirtations with Death by Carson
Necro-posting an old note from my Medium with some extra explication on the macabre.
Read on Substack

The Game is changing, and this is twice as true on college campuses, where the amphetamine black market is booming â€¦ Given my own experience and that of friends, I was surprised to see the positive effects [of meditation] were so mild, until I saw the meditation protocols. â€¦ Would you go to the gym for 5 minutes a day and expect any sort of change?
