ï»¿EDIT: as of late 2024, Iâ€™ve found my life partner. Weâ€™re in a non-monogamous relationship, so you can still fill in the form below or reach out directly if you might be interested in a flirtation or fling. Iâ€™ve left the rest of this doc unedited from the original.


I very much want a life partner who orients towards the world in a similar way as I do. Iâ€™m writing this document in the hope of finding her; please share it with women you think might be a good match. Iâ€™m male, 30, living in San Francisco, working in AI. Whether or not I have kids will depend on my partner (see section on that below). Iâ€™m open to going on dates with people who live elsewhere, but have trouble seeing myself living outside a major global city in the long term.


Here are five of my defining traits; Iâ€™d love to find a partner who shares them with me. If they resonate with you, fill in this form or reach out directly.


Growth
* I think of the world as full of opportunities waiting to be seized - which even if we canâ€™t get to yet, weâ€™ll be able to tomorrow. I want to be with someone who sees themselves as a work in progress, like I am; and whose default attitude is "why not?"

For me, growth mindset is closely entangled with the idea of making the future of technology go well, which is the focus of most of my work.


Intellectualism
* It's most natural for me to relate to the world in an analytical, systematizing way. I'd love to have a partner who, like me, is strongly driven to understand whatâ€™s going on around them, to grasp the intellectual edifice humanity has been building, and to fill in the gaps themselves - not just in academic domains, but anywhere their curiosity leads them. For a picture of what this looks like in me, try reading my blog or my twitter.


I often get along particularly well with people who read a lot as children, like I did. 


Teamwork
* I want a relationship which is deeply cooperative: two people building something in collaboration, where strong communication is the default and we trust that we can handle problems together. Some examples of how Iâ€™ve worked towards this in previous relationships:
   1. Scheduling an hour each week to raise issues and possible improvements.
   2. Taking a course on non-violent communication together.
   3. Doing circling together.


Rereading that list, it all soundsâ€¦ kinda serious? But the spirit Iâ€™m pointing towards is much less so: if we can laugh at all sorts of things (including ourselves) together, weâ€™re most of the way towards being a good team. And for me, being a good team is the essence of romance - everything else is built on top of that.


Towardsness
* By â€œtowardsnessâ€ I mean being motivated by actively wanting to move towards desirable outcomes, rather than just away from undesirable outcomes. The latter typically comes from fear-based motivation (as I write about at length here). I think fear-based motivation is far more extensive than most people typically recognize, and that excitement-based motivation which actually focuses on moving towards goals is a kind of superpower.

I previously formulated this point as a desire for a partner with prosocial motivations. But I now tend to think that overcoming fear (in particular deeply-rooted fear) is the main bottleneck to that, and that almost everyone would have pretty prosocial motivations if they were more emotionally integrated. And so Iâ€™m not really looking for a partner who cares deeply about any specific thing; Iâ€™m looking for a partner with the capacity to care deeply at all.


Playfulness
   * I balance the more serious traits above with an irreverent attitude towards life. I like spontaneous adventures, I like starting dancefloors, and I like thinking of rules as made to be broken. People are often surprised by how playful I am in person - it doesnâ€™t come through much in writing, where my intellectual side takes charge. (In this doc, my whimsical side keeps trying to slip things in, but my romantic side keeps overwriting them because it thinks finding a life partner is SERIOUS BUSINESS.)


The person Iâ€™m writing this for might not have all the traits Iâ€™ve listed (or might not yet know that she does). But because we care about the same things on a deep level, I think she would want to have them eventually - just as the traits that sheâ€™s looking for are probably the ones Iâ€™m already aiming for. Maybe we can develop them together.


A note on children


My main priority is finding the right partner; how many kids I have will largely depend on her preferences. Some possibilities I could be happy with:
   1. A partner who wants to have 3+ kids and to be the main caregiver for them.
   2. A partner who wants to have 1-2 kids and split responsibilities fairly evenly (but also get help from nannies etc, which I'm fortunately in a financial position to be able to pay for).
   3. A partner who doesn't want kids because she (and I) find their work very meaningful and we want to prioritize that.


I realize these are pretty different. One way of reconciling them: I want to have life projects with my partner; kids are one possible life project but not the only one; and so it's hard to be concrete before knowing who I want to co-create these life projects with. I'm not apathetic about kidsâ€”I think having kids is one of the most life-affirming things you can do. But I donâ€™t want to rule out being swayed towards other life trajectories by the right person.


Some other things about me


My guess is that, for the people Iâ€™m looking for, the traits Iâ€™ve talked about so far are likely to be the strongest signal that we should try going on a date. But here are some other facts about me that might help:
   * Iâ€™ve spent most of my career at frontier AGI labs, working on a wide range of different topics. Now I do independent research on what I consider to be the most impactful and interesting research directions in the world (a mix of AI governance and theoretical AI alignment). For an accessible introduction to my thinking, try this podcast. Iâ€™m excited about my work, and itâ€™s important to me.
   * I embrace life. I seize opportunities to dance, sing, travel, play practically any sport, read, socialize, and try new things. Iâ€™m energetic and adventurous.
   * I am fundamentally okay with myself, even as I strive to be better. I donâ€™t easily get flustered, angry, or insecure. Growing up in New Zealand gave me an underlying relaxed optimism about the world (although it's now often expressed via a very Californian type of ambition).
   * Iâ€™m unfussy about many conventionally-valued traits like a partnerâ€™s level of formal education, career trajectory, finances, etc.


I think my weakest traits from a dating perspective are that:
   * Iâ€™m not very empathetic on a gut level. This sometimes surprises people, because I'm unusually good at understanding and engaging with my own and others' emotions. But on an instinctive level, when Iâ€™m not actively trying to be empathetic, I still tend to default to thinking abstractly rather than putting myself in other people's shoes.
   * I work a lot, driven in part by my belief that technological progress (and particularly progress in AI) is going to accelerate a lot over the coming decades, potentially making this the most important century. This may be disconcerting for some potential partners.
   * Iâ€™m short for a guy.


Iâ€™m still on good terms with all of the women I dated seriously during the past five years; here are reviews from two of them:


"Richard is great. 5 out of 5 stars. It didn't work out with us but the quality of friendship we have now speaks for itself. He is one of the smartest people I know. Discussing things with him is great. Sharp and constructive. He has great friends. Absurdly good at any sport. Downside: bit chaotic, no taste for good food ðŸ˜‰"


â€œRichard is weirdly good at being in a relationship; I can think of three or four concrete ways I'm emotionally healthier after having dated him. One notable omission from this doc is the flip side of him being less empathetic than average on a gut level, which is that it feels easy to express feelings to him and negotiate conflict because he can accept intense emotions without getting caught up in them. He's more whimsical than the doc would suggest, though not less serious. Moreover, he is an excellent kisser and throws very good parties.â€


Here are some photos of me:
  
  





If you think we could be a good match (or you have a friend who might be), fill in my form, email me at richardcngo@gmail.com, tweet at me, tell a mutual friend to arrange a rendezvous, throw pebbles at my window, write me a song, or send me a document like this of your own! (If you're not sure what to say, tell me about a favorite book or song, or something you're looking forward to over the coming year.) If youâ€™re uncertain, please do err on the side of getting in touch - writing is much lower-bandwidth for discovering compatibility than meeting in person, and the heavy-tailed outcomes here are skewed very positively!

I'm definitely at least ketogenic for life, and possibly carnivore for life. 


I believe this is both optimal human nutrition, and beneficial to the environment at large. When a field of grains is harvested, countless birds, rodents, and other bugs and critters are killed. But from just one cow, you can eat for nearly an entire year. Ranches that practice regenerative ranching, such as White Oak Pastures, can actually have a carbon negative effect, reverse desertification, and be a tool to fight against climate change. And chances are, when you eat a steak, its source is fewer than 50 miles from where you're sitting. On the other hand, monocrop agriculture is terrible for the planet, creates runoff crises, extreme water use, depletes soil, and the food miles on processed grains and produce are astronomical. And besides, vegans fart more than cows do anyway. That's not just a quip. Studies show that vegans flatulate seven times more than someone on a standard American diet. And people on a carnivore diet do it seldomly altogether.

LDL cholesterol transports vitamins through the bloodstream and can also engulf pathogens and foreign substances much like a neutrophil. We've been pushing low cholesterol since the 1950s and metabolic disease has skyrocketed since... it's no wonder natural human immunity isn't as robust as it should be. Unless I meet my demise by some kind of violent or accidental end, I'm going to outlive all the people taking statins and eating low-fat diets. My cognitive function will also outlast the vast majority of theirs. 


For more information I invite you to check out The Cholesterol Code, or the work of Mary Enig on seed oils, or Sally Norton on oxalates, or Gary Taubes, Judy Cho, Nina Teicholz, doctors Jason Fung, Shawn Baker, Anthony Chaffee, Ken Berry, Lisa Wiedeman, Robert Kiltz, Paul Saladino... and more! With all of that being said, carnivore is my diet, but not my lifestyle or identity. It's important for my partner to know and understand where I am coming from and what I value, and I've written all of this because I understand that most people will have many questions, but it's not really something that I'll constantly be talking about.

Recently, I've resolved to intentionally cultivate community and create family, rather than assume this will all work out with minimal intervention on my part. Iâ€™d love to create a relationship with a community around it; a relationship that is in itself a family and that also generates more family in some form.  
Relationship leanings
Iâ€™m into monogamous relationships, ones that are co-located, and Iâ€™d love to be in a relationship that feels like a great team.  
Joy
I canâ€™t think of a lot to say about it other than: why not make a point of generating and savouring it?
Food
Yes. Please. Ideally vegetables. Moderate drinker, more of a savourer than a guzzler. Sweet tooth problem (cake I can guzzle for some reason?) 
Location
UK, London 
Are you open to relocating?
I can imagine doing this under some circumstances, and definitely know how to. Yet after moving back and forth across 3 continents for most of my adult life, Iâ€™m trying something newish (to me): staying in one place, becoming rooted. 


I also think Iâ€™ve exceeded the threshold of how many long distance relationships are sensible to have in one lifetime, so best if a partner and I live in roughly the same place.
What are you looking for in a partner?
Qualities I deeply appreciate include: kindness, curiosity, a general sense of presence, attentiveness, introspective skills, interest in bodies, not just in how they look but in how they are, and how they connect, co-regulation (â† which is more of a relational than individual attribute, but such a magic thing that I think worth mentioning.)


Iâ€™d like to be and to be with someone weâ€™d all want on a team; someone resourced, with skills and perspective to bring to the mix, someone who values learning and growth, someone who has my back as much as I have theirs. 
What do you think a relationship even is?
I think of a relationship as a creation; something we cultivate intentionally, consciously, caringly; something we feel worthwhile to maintain and nurture even when that takes a little effort after the butterflies stop fluttering all the time. 


Iâ€™d love to create a relationship that changes and expands as we do; that forms a secure ground from which we can step out into the world, have rich experiences, change, grow, and bring those changes and that growth back to each other and watch them enrich our relationship. 


I also think of it as bowls of soup on the couch in winter, watching each other's bags at the train station so we donâ€™t have to lug them to the toilet, arguing well, giggles, surprises, whispers, building community and creating some form of family e.g. with children, dogs, neighbours, friends, or a subset of these.
Can we just be friends?
If weâ€™re compatible as friends, yes please. I cherish friendship and have space and time for new ones.

I've been divorced since March, 2021, and I'm thankful that it was a drama-free event. My ex-wife is a good woman but we just drifted apart. I've done a lot of work on myself since then, and I have a good handle on the things I did wrong. If I get a second chance at love, I'll know how to make it work.


Because of the divorce and my retirement that followed soon after, I really began to examine my life. It turns out I'm not the center of the universe after all! Okay, I wasn't really that self-centered, but I did realize that my greatest rewards come from service to others, whether it's working to be a better partner and friend, volunteering, or just doing simple things that might make someone's day just a little nicer. Compassion, kindness, generosity, awareness, gratitude, honesty, humility and even that trait some guys don't understand - vulnerability.


Being open to life and living fearlessly are part of my new outlook. One example: I recently began bodyboarding ("boogey boarding"), and not long ago I had a magical experience - I was surrounded by dolphins as they fed, some as close as 10 feet away. One rose up out of the water to take a look at me. I was the closest human by quite a bit; everyone else was a couple of hundred feet away or more. That put a smile on my face and laughter in my heart for two full days. It felt like a personal gift from the universe. You can't experience life if you don't show up for it.  


There's a term I heard recently - ambivert. It describes someone who has the traits of both an extrovert and introvert. It seems to describe me, although I lean a little toward extroversion. I volunteer as a docent at a very popular local museum, so I get to be part tour guide, part educator and part entertainer. It's perfect for me, and I come away with a sense of joy.


I'm a glass half-full kind of guy. Sure, sometimes the level drops a little below the halfway mark - I'm human - but more often the glass is almost overflowing.


I'm not religious but I'm trying to find my way spiritually. (There's a story about how I came to finally acknowledge my spiritual side, something I kept suppressed for decades.)


I've got a pretty sharp sense of humor (or at least I think so), but I know how to rein it in so I don't offend people. I don't take myself too seriously. Sometimes I wake up laughing. But I don't overplay my sense of humor - I'm presentable in public and I won't embarrass you.


Although I don't have any pets, I love 'em - cats, dogs, birds, just about anything that has even the slightest personality.
  

I'm a natural-born romantic (I love surprising the one I love with little tokens and acts) and I respect a woman's boundaries.


Having someone special in my life is important to me, but not so important that I'd rush carelessly into it. Being in a romantic relationship isn't a one-way thing for me - I want to give at least as much as I get. After all, I'm not the center of the universe!






Factoids


* 64 years old as of the end of June of 2024
* 5' 6"

* Retired (with a stable income)
* No children (but I get along great with them)

   * Photojournalist (also time as a columnist, editor and illustrator)
   * IT professional
* Lots of funny stories from a life of derring-doâ€¦ and derring-don't.

ï»¿Meta: this doc is oriented toward a long term romantic relationship. Iâ€™m also open to more â€œcasualâ€ possibilities, but if thatâ€™s what youâ€™re after you should probably ignore this doc.


  



When I was 11 years old, as my 12th birthday was approaching, I noticed that the people younger than me tended to have grand ambitions - going to space or becoming president or, in my case, building a new continent. But the people older than me generally did not have such ambitions. Clearly something happened to nearly everyone as they got older, such that they gave up on their dreams and decided to get married, buy a house and have 2.5 kids instead. I was terrified that would happen to me.


So I swore very hard never to do that - never to embrace a life of mediocrity. And that basically worked.


I want a cure for aging. I want weekend trips to the moon. I want flying cars and an indestructible body and tiny genetically-engineered dragons. I want to understand minds, be able to build them and edit them and read off their internals. I want things well beyond humanityâ€™s current bounds, and the focus of my life is pursuing those goals wherever they may lead.


What I also want - very badly - is a partner for that pursuit. And I do mean a partner - not a hanger-on, not an enthusiastic supporter, but someone with grand ambitions of their own and capabilities on par with my own or perhaps even greater. I want someone who can actually be a peer in pushing beyond humanityâ€™s current abilities. Because that is what I need, in order to feel romantic love; nothing else seems to work.


â€¦ and thatâ€™s it. Thereâ€™s lots of little things I could say - I am sadly quite straight, I love dancing, etc, etcâ€¦ but Iâ€™ve said the part which matters most and I donâ€™t want to water it down further. If a partnership of pushing beyond humanityâ€™s current abilities and making the world more to our tastes is something you want, you should get in touch and we can find out if weâ€™re a good fit along other axes.


If you want to scope me out, I write a lot on LessWrong. A message on LessWrong is the most expedient way to get in touch if we donâ€™t already have another channel; Facebook or the myriad of slack spaces also work if our social circles overlap already.

ï»¿Date Me Doc: Steven Elleman
Feel free to send questions, feedback, snark, love letters, etc to steven.elleman@gmail.com . 


The intent of this doc is to put some basic facts about myself online. If these facts feel aligned, then reach out. Some folks have reached out to say this kind of doc â€œspoils the mysteryâ€. To me, the mystery is our emergent dynamic. It is what uniquely arises from us, what dance we co-create. 


The previous version of this doc was aggressively autistic, feel free to check it out if you like walls of text: Date Me Doc: Steven Elleman (old)
About Me 
I worked as a professional software engineer for 7 years, I quit last year to try to align my main life threads into one coherent braid. There are three threads in my life: (1) communal living, (2) secular religious exploration, and (3) â€œDWebâ€. 


(1) matters to me because thereâ€™s magic to communal living that has made my life so much richer, and I want family in a communal context. (2) is about my relationship with myself and relationship with others. The magic that (1) offers feels like the right environment for (2), and Iâ€™ve been exploring different secular religious communities and running experimental retreats. (3) is a technical movement about a bottom-up version of the Internet and our digital world. I think (1) is the right vehicle for (3). Communal living is all about navigating shared resources and infrastructure; adding home servers into the mix makes a lot of sense. 


What unifies these threads is simple: home. If I had a home with a community of people I deeply admire and love I think thatâ€™d satisfy most of my needs. Iâ€™m interested in building a new kind of home from the bottom up, one that makes sense to me. This is both the simplest and grandest kind of endeavor, creating my own community-home is a constant act of world-building. I long for a partner-lover-friend who wants to build it with me.
Romantic Dynamic 
I build intimacy slowly. Using the body as a metaphor, I build intimacy through head -> gut -> heart -> sex. Head: on an intellectual level I need to think we have aligned values and goals. Gut: I need to feel safe with you, that youâ€™re a stable, reliable, and integrous person. Only after my head and gut feel safe do my internal inhibitions drop, and I feel permissioned to fall in love. And only after that do I feel permissioned to feel sexual attraction. My story for this order and degree of inhibition is that I fear being trapped in a partnership similar to my parents â€“ if Iâ€™m going to be committed I need to feel deeply aligned. Typically the way I build intimacy is through shared projects and lots of talking or writing. Romantically so far my pattern has been heterosexual and serially monogamous, and I would like to be a father.


Ideologically I subscribe to â€œrelational presenceâ€; I believe relationships of all kinds should honor whatever is present and alive, over stories of the relationship. What does a shared commitment to presence and aliveness look like? When stories are prioritized, feelings can be repressed out of a sense of responsibility or obligation. This is putting the cart before the horse. Itâ€™s putting intellectual stories over feelings which often represent a deeper and more embodied truth. In rational positivist thinking, the intellect trumps subjectivity and feelings. I believe this perceived superiority is at the root of many contemporary problems; it amounts to gaslighting. Feelings are facts. If feelings are facts, theyâ€™re always valid and legitimate. All wants, desires, fears, aversions, boundaries, etc are first-class citizens; stories must follow from the feelings, the cart must follow the horse. This allows radical honesty and transparency, eliminates unhealthy shame and repression, and ensures stories are constantly brought back into alignment with whatâ€™s actually being felt, whatâ€™s actually present and alive.


The stories we tell often feel rooted in a desire for safety and control, fear of loss can prevent relationships from changing in necessary and beautiful ways. I see possession in conventional monogamous relationships as an attempt to prevent change and loss; in the process it puts the cart before the horse, it can put the story of the relationship before appreciation of whatâ€™s real. Loss is inevitable. People change. Weâ€™re going to die. I want to feel safe in the impermanence and change. Beyond acceptance of loss is savoring the preciousness of life. Denial of impermanence prevents savoring, it leads to clinging to stories and grasping for control that simply doesnâ€™t exist. It leads to attachment to a story or image of self and partner over who they actually are, and in the process, aliveness is stifled, and self-deception takes over. 


I want to see and know you as you are, and I want to be seen and known in turn. I want to honor you in your full aliveness, and even if itâ€™s brief and fleeting, at least itâ€™ll be real. 


This belief has been shifting all my relationships pretty significantly over the last year, and Iâ€™m still seeing how it coalesces with my historical romantic dynamic. 
Romantic Archetypes 
There appear to be recurring archetypes that Iâ€™m drawn to. â€œAutisticâ€ â€“ women who emphasize intellect, principles, analytical reasoning â€“ I feel safe with this archetype and thereâ€™s a shared interest in systems and reasoning. â€œPost-Rock Bottomâ€ â€“ women who had to go through emotional turbulence and have hit rock bottom before â€“ I admire the resilience and acceptance of this archetype, often it has emotional depth and contrast, which I love. I often like being a â€œgroundâ€ for my partner and seem to be attracted to depressive and bipolar women â€“ I like being a source of hope, optimism, care. â€œShamanicâ€ â€“ I often like women who marry a high degree of sensitivity, attunement and intuition with spirituality. â€œFieryâ€ â€“ I want a warrior. I like strong women. Beneath my outer layers of personality is a lot of fire. Iâ€™ve noticed I like women who are fierce, I know I can handle them, and I want them to be able to handle me. I can like the â€œBratâ€ archetype â€“ I like being of service, but I like taking control in other contexts â€“ some brattiness can strike a nice balance.  


If youâ€™re some combination of Fiery Post-Rock Bottom Shamanic Autist Brat please reach out!

You're having a good day? You will not find a more bubbly, more enthusiastic, more supportive person to share it with. Nadia is thirsty for life, and she will show you how to drink your day with gusto. Her shenanigans are legendary and her laughter is more contagious than a pandemic.
You're having a bad day? She will hold you and show you that it's okay to be vulnerable, that it's okay to be human. With her, heaven is just a hug away. Nadia deeply cares about those around her, and she will always be there for you. She is a person both sharp and soft, both strong and gentle, both wise and curious. Hi, I'm Harry!
Hi, I'm Harry!
Note: You may prefer to see my profile on
this other useful website
, which has both more detail and more pictures of me, but you'll need to sign up for that to see the whole thing.
Hi! I'm Harry Altman, aka Sniffnoy.  You might have encountered me on the
internet before.  I do math, and in particular I can talk your ear off about
the problem of writing numbers with ones, addition, and multiplication!  And
lots of variants of the problem.  I won't do that here though, I'll save
that for later.  :D
Also I like infinities.  I've also been working a bunch on doing silly
things with infinities.  This is actually much easier, but unfortunately
it's way harder to explain to people!  Again, best saved for another time.
:)  Also various other math things, like some neat Fibonacci things
recently, but, uh, this isn't supposed to be a research statement, so I'll
move on to a different topic. :P
I don't actually have an academic position anywhere, so this past 5 years
I've worked a programming job to support my math habit. :)  I was writing an
Ethereum smart contract debugger, if you're interested; but that's come to a
close now so now I have a lot more time to get other things done again!
OK so the thing is... like, I guess this is a place to describe oneself,
but I'm kind of averse to doing that?  I guess a big thing there is that I
worry about verbal overshadowing and also creating fixity, that by
describing myself I will thereby cause myself to identify with those
descriptions, which is something I want to avoid.
So, well, I guess I will try to say only things that are quite definitely
true, or to show rather than telling!
I guess, I like things that are a bit off from what people expect.
Sometimes, as in my mathematical work, these things are quite natural -- but
nature doesn't always meet your expectations!  Or (to take a page from
Yudkowsky's book), I should say that people's expectations don't always meet
nature. ðŸ˜  Sometimes nice questions have nasty answers, and I like to
disgust people with them. :D  And sometimes nasty-seeming constructions have
nice results, and I like to amaze people with them!
But I'm interested in the artificial as well as the natural; a thing I
find really fascinating is, like, bizarrely complicated conventions and
understanding where they come from and all the weird cases they generate.
Things like text encoding (particularly Unicode) and data encoding in
computers; unusual calendars (it's fun to explain the Hebrew calendar to
people ðŸ˜); and other such things.  I am trying to more often say "huh,
that's a strange word, I wonder where it comes from?" and look up its
etymology.  So many things that appear to not make sense, the reason is, it
used to make sense, but then it wasn't updated when circumstances changed!
And I really like learning about the history of how that occurred.
I also like taking pictures of the local wildlife, which mostly means
bugs and birds. :)  Here in New York mostly birds, I don't see a lot of good
bugs here.  Although there are rats! :D  Of course, rats don't like light or
people, which makes photographing them tricky, but it can be done!  Back in
Ann Arbor I'd see a lot more good bugs.
Uh, what are other good stories for illustrating myself?  Um, here's one
that comes to mind.  Once, I was visiting my friends Colin and Aviva out in
Chicago, and we were in the car, along with their dog, Gately.  (Gately has
since died, unfortunately.)  I was in the back seat, and Gately was in the
center of the car.  And I thought, you know, dogs are always sniffing each
other's butts. Gately's butt is right there; I could totally sniff it.  So
uh I tried sniffing Gately's butt.  It stunk!  Not that much though.  I
don't think I really learned anything from doing this. :P
(Perhaps my favorite thing that anyone has ever said about me: "Harry,
you are very good at making arguments, but you are not good at not doing
annoying things with the cat toy." ðŸ˜)

more pictures of me!)

profileDetails.fullText:
Here's looking at me â€“ Telegraph
Here's looking at me
Luca
May 17, 2024
Here's looking at me
Luca
I am a run-of-the-mill carbon-based life form, living on the planet currently known as Earth (or so I've been told). If you're reading this, it's highly likely you've come across my profile on Hinge. This must be the fourth or fifth time I've created an account there. It's not that I haven't had any luck -- I've connected with some interesting people, but obviously nothing that has worked out well enough to stop me wanting to go back.
I thought I'd write a profile (a "
date-me doc
" of sorts) for those piqued enough by the very limited window provided by Hinge to want to get to know me more, but on second thoughts I thought I'd do something different. So here's a list of reasons NOT to date me:
I'm married. No two ways about it: some time in 2005, I entered into a civil marriage, which is still valid on paper. The marriage didn't work out, and my wife and I have lived separately since 2018. Neither of us see the point in getting a divorce as of now, but this will obviously change if there's a good enough reason for it. Needless to say, neither of us has problems with the other seeking other romantic interests.
Steinbeck once referred to poor Americans seeing themselves as "temporarily embarrassed millionaires". Well in my case the pandemic and its aftermath has found me in a similar circumstance of temporary embarrassment (which I hope is truly temporary). I work with languages and have freelanced all my working life -- something that worked just fine, despite the unavoidable ups and downs, until a few years ago. Every now and then, it does begin to look like things might pick up again, but only time will tell if they really do. So all you prospective sugar babies can happily walk right past me and I hope you manage to find your pot(belly) of gold. But for those of you who might still be willing to overlook this: I have never been that interested in making money or other indicators of worldly success. Right now, the only interest I still have in doing so is to uphold my commitment to my children (did I mention I have children? Well I do: two of the most wonderful persons I've ever had the pleasure of knowing).
I can be a bit of a curmudgeon -- it's hard to get me excited about what's happening in the world outside (or even convincing me of its existence on some days), at least not for its own worth. In the right company, however, even the most humdrum, everyday activities take on the aura of the most exciting thing the world has ever known, and more than anything else, this quest of mine is for that right company.
That's it for now, but I'm sure there are many more reasons to weigh the prospect of seeing and going out (or staying in) with me very carefully. I promise to add them to the list as and when they occur to me.

I want to net eight figures (or more) over my lifetime by being amazing at tech and startups with reasonably prosocial impact.  This has been a long throughline in my life.  I taught myself to code at age eight.  Then I skipped college and went straight to work at Google, at age twenty.  In the ten years since, I've been building my business acumen, inhaling technical knowledge, developing a grand unified theory of engineering productivity, and attempting startups intermittently.  None of them have taken off yet.


In the event of a wealth explosion: in addition to buying a lot of mosquito nets for charity, I'd like to create a beautiful, rejuvenating dwelling space that's quiet and green and close to a city and looks like something off Pinterest.  Maybe not just for me-and-mineâ€”maybe an eco-village?  A giant attic in which to keep brilliant neurodivergent artists and inventors?

I get a bad feeling in my gut about win/lose status games (though I'm admittedly driven to seek others' admiration and fondness)â€”but I like living authentically and healthfully, and nurturing the same in the people whose lives I touch.  To the extent that those goals require resource abundance and social capital, they tend to get folded into conversations about status.  That can lead to some inner confusion, since I do have both a functioning limbic brain and a conscience that's skeptical as hell of it. Sandra Bemâ€™s androgyny framework is the actual beeâ€™s knees.  Hereâ€™s the rundown:


There are culturally tagged â€œmasculineâ€ and â€œfeminineâ€ modalities of thought, feeling, and behavior.
A fully developed human has mindfully cultivated both in themself through a combination of deliberate self-work and acquiring varied life experiences.
That human is the Avatar of shitty gender constructs, bending all the elements at once:
competence and warmth, yin and yang, nurturance and agency, assertiveness and receptivityâ€¦
According to Dr. Bem, they've risen to the rank of â€œandrogynousâ€, the peak of human potential.


Dr. Bem came up with this idea and developed research tools to measure people on a two-axis system of â€œfemininityâ€ and â€œmasculinityâ€, with the really cool people landing in the upper-right quadrant, high on both scales.  Those folks can display â€œsituational appropriatenessâ€ across a wide variety of contexts, either by switching modes or by blending both modes at once.


Bemâ€™s androgyny feels like a cousin to two of my other favorite ideas in philosophy, which are the golden mean (watching out for â€œtoo muchâ€ and â€œtoo littleâ€ in literally all things) and Hegelian dialectics (thesis/antithesis/synthesis).


So, am I masculine?  Thatâ€™s a very solid â€œyes-andâ€.

I'm captivated by sensations and will visibly surrender to joy when I look out over the hills, snuggle up under a soft blanket, or take the first bite of a good meal. Iâ€™ve developed a view that temperament and neurotype really are what gender is cracked up to be.  People empirically differ in their essential, embodied naturesâ€”meaning blank slatism is falseâ€”but the pink/blue bucket system is a stain on our culture.  Temperament and neurotype show uncountable natural variations, giving rise to â€œendless forms most beautiful and strangeâ€ among individuals.  People are best bucketed by their contextually relevant distinctions (I call them â€œCoRDsâ€), which vary completely from one context to the next.  Reproductive sex class is almost never a CoRD, unless we're actually talking about intercourse or family planning!


The truth about a personâ€™s talents, instincts, and proclivities dwells in that person, and the optimally developed version of that person is bespoke and exists independently of cultural archetypes.  I don't know, nor do I expect ever to know, what traits statistically correlate with reproductive sex class at a population level in a truly culture-fair society.  I do know that if you're dealing with (for example) a young Norah Vincent, who, as an AFAB child in the early 1970's, persisted doggedly in wearing jeans and climbing trees despite every imaginable social pressure to the contrary, then you love and embrace that lilâ€™ lesbian tomboy from the bottom of your heart.  And for goodness's sake, can we please make heroes rather than martyrs of our highly sensitive AMAB children?


What this means for parenting is: Iâ€™m going to let my kids show me what their natural talents and interests are, and then Iâ€™m going to nurture those without too much editorializing.  (Yes, rooting out bias and subtle influences is a hard problem, but still.)


  

The user selects negative-one genders, and the fortress bursts into flames.
Case study: BayHouseWarming
In 2021, as I was moving from Seattle back to the Bay Area, I tried founding a group house with 4â€“6 ambitious residents from among my friend group.  I affectionately called this project the Bay House.


My vision was to gather folks who would positively peer-pressure each other to achieve their dreams more proactively, in a warm and nurturing environment where we all enjoyed one another, shared meals, kept up with each other's lives, and did activities together.  (Looking back three years later, I recognize this as a variation of â€œfamilyâ€, which I now call one of my core values.)


I shot for the moon and landed in the treetops: I succeeded in establishing the house with a total of 3 residents, plus a fourth who visited for a time.


I took on sole responsibility for furnishing our new nestâ€”everything from budgeting to design to logistics.  When one housemate's parents came to see the place, they pulled me aside and said, â€œYou put all this together?  This is not some bachelor-pad setup.  This is a grown-up house,â€ nodding with a raised brow.  That's still one of my favorite compliments I've ever received.


I decided to plan and host a housewarming party, hoping to knit together different parts of my friend group and establish the house as a social venue.  Naturally, I named the party â€œBayHouseWarmingâ€.


I still have the planning sheet in my personal archives:


  

Is this â€œmasculineâ€ or â€œfeminineâ€?  You tell me.


The unchecked items got done in time; I just never went back to check the checkboxes.  By then, the list had served its purpose.


I also made this document to help track food prep.  It's an early example of what I now call [pun redacted]â€”my personal survival tool for C.W.N. (cooking while neurodivergent).


Here's the rest of the story in photos:

(The cans are all soft drinks, most with low sugar.

every time a visitor came over, something new would appear on it.
We got poems, lewd drawings, people's hopes and dreams, more lewd drawingsâ€¦


  

A chessboard is to some of my friends as a paper bag is to cats.

It was the kind of dinner you'd want to eat outside.

On good terms with my ex
At 23, I met and fell in love with a very charming human, who is now working on her own dating doc, which will get a solid endorsement from me.  [UPDATE: Here it is.]
That relationship continued for about eight years.  We lived together for four of those years, then moved apart.
Finally, we decided that we had irreconcilable differences and it wouldn't make sense for us to marry.  Our paths have disentangled somewhat, and weâ€™re currently in a cooling-off period of low contact, but this person is still like family to me and to my relatives.
Expect her to continue playing a role in my life!  Sheâ€™ll likely appear at family gatherings in the future.  Itâ€™s possible sheâ€™ll be â€œAuntie Aliciaâ€ to my kids.
How I'm searching
Using dateme.directory, I ran a database query for every F and NB doc worldwide.  (My data cutoff was 2024-04-14.)  Then I carefully read all 130 of them, skipping one.  That part took a total of 10 hours.  I built a spreadsheet as I went, recording my feelings about each doc on a dual 7-point scaleâ€”separately measuring the strength of my positive response and the strength of my negative response.  Both scales work like this:


7â€”overwhelmingly present
6â€”clearly present
5â€”weakly present
4â€”ambivalent or unclear
3â€”weakly absent
2â€”clearly absent
1â€”overwhelmingly absent


I recorded my data in normalized form so I could write relational queries.
Then I wrote a query to generate a bubble chart visualizing the frequencies of different score pairs:


  

When I look at the size of the 5/6, 6/6, and 7/6 bubbles,
a certain Taylor Swift song starts playing in my head.


I also wrote a query to grab the data records forming the lower-right portion of the chart (high positive scores, low negative scores) and sort them in a certain way.  That tells me which docs to revisit at length.


From there, intuition takes the wheel.

The reality is that ideal love is only possible between two independent, mature and sincere people. Therefore, it is essential that you first decide to improve yourselves. If you feel from the bottom of your heart in your relationship that you are not regarded as you should be, I hope you have the courage and dignity to break off such an unhappy relationship. True love does not come between two people who smother each other; it can only come between two strong people who are sure of their individuality. A superficial person will only have superficial relationships. If you want to experience true love, it is important first to sincerely develop a strong identity. True love is certainly not doing what the other person wants, or trying to be what you are not. If someone loves you deeply, he or she will never push you to act against your will or involve you in anything dangerous for you.
Daisaku Ikeda

Seeking Meaningful Connections
That are Beautifully Complex
  

  Prologue:  the â€œWhyâ€ Behind It All
Sometimes, I think we forget how awesome we are--just us--on our own--no excuses or regrets in our unadulterated singularity of quasar magnificence. Recently, I have been thinking about life, about how now I am in my thirties, how life definitely has not turned out the way I thought it would, and how, as odd as it sounds, I am so glad it hasn't. 
I also have been thinking about how though I would like to meet my person, and be there for them when they wake up in the morning, having them be there to pull me into a hug which makes me not get up at 5:30 AM every morning.  I have been considering how I would like someone to share my life with, able to fall asleep next to them on the taxi ride home from the subway and know they will wake me up when we get there and for that person to have me to be there for them in a similar-yet-different way based on their own individual desires for a partnerâ€™s presence in their life.  However, I also realize that if these things do not ever happen and I never meet such a person, I will be alright with that too.
As a demisexual, if dating has taught me anything in my limited experience, it is that I would rather be alone, than alone in a relationship. I honestly still do not know what I want, because honestly, I feel it is not about wants, but about being there for people and vice versa.
  

(Pre-Covid Me @ Stowe, Vermont, Von Trapp Brewery)
Have I given up on meeting "The One?" The answer is no, I have not. I have occasionally wondered if he is lost in a desert riding a camel backwards in the wrong direction for the time it is taking to have him cross my path--or if I am??!! The other thing I have wondered is if he is lost in the Bermuda Triangle playing with magnets, or maybe if he has found his perfect elsewhere--it could happen, and if it did, more power to him.
Sometimes, I wonder if somewhere, "My Person" is wondering similarly as they mosey through desserts, play with magnets in the Triangle, or consider if I too have met "my perfect" elsewhere, (which I have not, though I have met some "notâ€“so-perfect" in this journey, but I digress).
But I have indeed given up on "finding love" being seamless, easy, and clear. Love really is a journey as Ruell sings, and sometimes like Malec in Shadowhunters, you have to go to hell and back twice for the ones you love, and even then, there is no guarantee--only hope, and trust in the ones we love and live for and sometimes who we are lucky enough to live with.
So, despite things not working out sometimes, despite the unplanned for rude grenades and emotional suicide bombers we may meet on a date,  we can wear Mithril armor, like Frodo, and ward off the Ring Wraiths dressed up as ordinary humanoids. 
Nowadays, I also spend time just living life, riding motorbikes down roads at night to the swaying of lit Lunar New Year lanterns, feeling the cool air and enjoying the moon above me, going to the beach in the morning to see what it is like when the day is waking on the ocean, and being grateful for the present solitude, whether it remains forever, or is changed in an instant.
If I ever do meet "The One," how will I know it is him? Well, if a man is riding a camel backwards across the beach one morning I may just go up and ask him why it took him so long to cross the Sahara, but in all seriousness, I think it will be in the surety, in the kindness and care, in the quiet considerations, and in the fact that they like almost everything about me and I feel the same way about them--that they are my version of Puen, and I am their non-nagging equivalent of Talay from the Thai series, Vice Versa, and that it is not about if we can imagine the world without one another, but that we can ONLY imagine it with each other--in every universe. Is that cheesy and pie-in-the-sky? Perhaps, but I will wait for good dairy products and pastries until the cows (or camels as the case may be) come home.
So at the end of the day, I think the thing that matters is to trust our journeys and to realize that home and the road to it may be different than we expect. It may not be a picket fence yard in suburbia or an apartment in Manhattan. Home may end up being a treehouse in the jungle or a mountain villa in the Himalayas. Our home may be us and our partner with our kids, us alone in our comfy hobbit hole, like Bilbo, it could end up being us and our delightful roomies, or us and the kids the universe gave us in ways we never planned. But no matter how the road is or what home looks like, it is our road and our home, and that is what our heart beats through and to.

As previously mentioned, I plan to adopt children in the future. While I would be delighted if a partner wanted to co-parent with me, this is not a requirement or expectation. I am fully prepared to undertake the adoption process and care for the children on my own, both emotionally and financially.
  

(Coming back from an adventure. . . Autumn 2024) 
By sharing this upfront, I hope potential partners feel reassured that there is no pressure or obligation to take on financial or legal responsibilities for my future children. While I would love to have a supportive and involved partner in my family life, I fully respect it if that is not something they are comfortable with or ready for.
To address potential concerns, I have made arrangements to ensure my familyâ€”including any future adopted childrenâ€”will be cared for in the unlikely event of my passing. I appreciate the thoughtfulness of a partner considering this aspect, but I want to be clear that I do not expect them to take on any legal or caregiving responsibilities.
My intention in bringing up this topic is not to be blunt or morbid, but to provide transparency and alleviate concerns. If my desire to adopt is a dealbreaker, I kindly ask that such individuals refrain from contacting me, as this is a deeply important part of my life plan.
I consider myself an even-tempered person. On the rare occasions I feel upset, I prefer to step back, calmly identify the specific issues, and communicate them clearly without raising my voice. I welcome respectful discussions and disagreements, but I am strongly opposed to anyone trying to demand something from me. I value respecting othersâ€™ autonomy and privacy, and I tend to keep disagreements private unless directly relevant or asked about.
While I am generally easy-going and accommodating, I hold firm to my autonomy. Some people are surprised when they encounter this, as it may seem out of character, but I believe respecting each otherâ€™s autonomy is crucial in any relationship. I expect the same consideration I extend to others.
I understand that not everyone shares this view, and I respect their right to live as they choose. At the same time, I believe a healthy relationship requires mutual respect, including allowing space for each otherâ€™s beliefs and opinions. That said, I am open to changing my mind if presented with a well-reasoned, patient, and respectful argument.
Despite what these caveats may imply, I am a calm, relaxed person. My goal in sharing these boundaries is not to intimidate, but to save both myself and potential partners time and confusion, and to lay a foundation for honest, mutually respectful connections.
Ending Thoughts and Contact Information:
Thank you for reading this far! Please feel free to email me if youâ€™re interested in exploring a possible relationship, or even if you simply think we might make good friends.
Either way, I truly appreciate your time and consideration, and I wish you the very best on your journey.

"Outdoorsy Adventurer Seeking Partner for Life's Journey
San Fransico / San Jose / Morgan Hill 
At 41, I've rekindled my love for the great outdoors â€“ whether it's casting a line into a serene ocean or pitching a tent under a starlit sky, count me in. After a 15-year relationship, I've spent the past year and three months rediscovering myself, diving into books, and embracing the peace of meditation. Sobriety has become a pillar of my personal growth journey, and I'm committed to living my best life. 100% 


Music pulses through my veins, and I thrive on the energy of live concerts and festivals. But beyond the beats, I'm searching for someone to share in life's highs and lows. Whether we're cracking up at a comedy show or cuddling up for a scare with a good horror flick, I believe in making every moment count.


If you're ready to embark on an adventure of a lifetime â€“ filled with laughter, love, and endless possibilities â€“ let's connect and see where the journey takes us.


Iâ€™m Looking for a caring, confident woman with a sense of humor. If you like the outdoors, traveling is always a plus. Iâ€™m more attracted to your personality and who you are as a woman. Looks fade away and go away, your attitude toward life makes you for you. 




I disable social media, I want to start meeting people with adventures, not viewing them through apps. 


Feel free to contact me at vt7846@gmail.com

ï»¿About me


* 38 years old


* 5â€™8â€ (Donâ€™t care about your height; Iâ€™ve dated women who are taller than me barefoot and Iâ€™m not bothered by it. Obviously, itâ€™s okay if you have a preference.) 


* Based in NYC (Currently on sabbatical in Argentina and working on some personal goals.)


* Agnostic/Spiritual 
Spirituality in the sense of my understanding of the world through what I know from science, experience, reflection, etc. Belief systems are also connected to language.

* Divorced; no kids
The divorce was in 2017. The marriage was practical and beneficial to both of us. But we were also in love - so not just a practical arrangement either. 


   * Donâ€™t smoke (prefer that you don't, or you're trying to quit). Rarely drink (donâ€™t mind if you do).


Photos


  

	  

	  

  

	







  

	



How I spend my time


For work (as defined in the conventional sense), I do machine learning in tech.

My background is actually in applied math, which I love. I enjoy using my quantitative skills at work. But I value things outside of work a lot, in terms of how I interact with and contribute to society.


I really value expression in life, whether itâ€™s through the written word or through movement. Some of my interests:


   * Dance: Itâ€™s been a non-trivial part of my life for at least a decade now. Iâ€™ve always been moved by music (although I didnâ€™t have the chance to learn music/dance formally growing up). And being able to express music is what I love the most about dance.

   * Movement practice like yoga, fitness classes and aerial hoop (this is my latest obsession as of a year ago - I always try to have some things that are hard for me to keep me humble and motivated to grow, and some things where I can feel good about myself).

   * Written words: I love to read (when I can these days) and write creatively. Within fiction, I love any flavor of existentialism.


      * Tennis. Really any racquet sport: ping pong, badminton, pickleball (I gave in)

      * Cooking: I cook for myself and love what I make for myself more than any restaurant food.


         * Travel: Iâ€™ve traveled a lot, both solo and with partners. Thereâ€™s a wide variety of things that interest me: foreign cultures, nature, road trips.


         * Volunteering: a bunch of different things from childrenâ€™s health and education to homelessness and food security. 
Relationship stuff
Things I value
(both in others and about myself)


         * Empathy: I just want to be around people who care about others. Iâ€™m empathetic and itâ€™s so easy for me to care about my partner in long term relationships. Itâ€™s nice when we can look out for each other in our own ways and our strengths can be complementary. Two people thinking for both!


         * Authenticity/sincerity: I just like being myself and I appreciate people who can just share time with me and maybe we see through each other a bit during the time we interact. Itâ€™s what I enjoy in any kind of connection, even non-romantic ones.


         * Open-minded: I mean in the sense of questioning your own assumptions about life. Iâ€™m curious about the deep stuff in life and am very aware that all of my beliefs are also connected to my personal experience and that a new experience or a new rational argument has the potential to change that belief. I may have a high confidence about some of my beliefs based on what Iâ€™ve experienced, but Iâ€™m always open to learning a different perspective even it that doesnâ€™t make sense to me at that time.

         * Communication: I think it really goes both ways. This is the mental model that I want to keep in mind for myself:
            * As a speaker, I try to express my needs trying my best not to hurt my partner.
            * As a listener, I have to be ready to hear the hard stuff without taking it as a judgement about myself.
Both are hard and I know Iâ€™ll fail a lot. But itâ€™s a kindness practice the same way I work on exercising my body. In the end, everything is negotiable.
Dating style


If we decide we might be a match, I'd prefer to do a brief video chat or a quick coffee date sooner rather than messaging back and forth. I'm sure you're great, but until I know you, I like to prioritize my little free time for my hobbies and with my real life communities. Iâ€™m happy to answer anything specific thatâ€™s missing here before we connect further.
Relationship style
            * I prefer monogamy, but as I said about anything within a relationship, this also falls under something thatâ€™s negotiable.


            * Sex is an important part of the relationship but all the values I think are important for a relationship as a whole are the important aspects here as well: Communicating needs, trying to listen without judgement, etc. GGG as the kids say.

            * Intimacy: Physical touch, showing affection with touch and spending time together with non-sexual intimacy are also very important to me. I donâ€™t need all of these to be important to you as well, but if itâ€™s difficult for you to express through touch, Iâ€™d miss that non-verbal communication.
Kids
               * I donâ€™t have any kids yet. 
               * I love kids and Iâ€™m good with kids. (I have volunteered, and still do, in programs with kids and also with kids/adults on the spectrum.)
               * Iâ€™m open to having kids.
               1. If my partner is sure about not wanting kids, itâ€™d be far easier for me to choose that option.
               2. I think planning to have kids is a promise to the life that you decide to bring into the world. I think itâ€™s a responsibility that you decide to take on as a couple very consciously when the relationship is in that place.
How to reach me?
Write to me 
               * if you think we might be a good match, or
               * if something about my profile resonated with you and youâ€™d like to talk about it even if you donâ€™t think weâ€™re a good match.

ï»¿Updated November 2024


Hello everyone!


I imagine you are here because you really want to find your person. If you want to check to see if you are physically attracted to me, before you read my essay, scroll past the words and you shall find a lot of recent photos. 


So much of what I have realized on this long journey to finding my person, is that perhaps I am not meant to have â€œmy personâ€. Maybe this path is not meant for me. I feel more of a sense of peace about this now, versus a year ago, when I was doing a significant amount of grieving regarding being very single and childless, despite my best efforts to create that life for myself. 


Though I have surrendered to not forcing the river, so to speak, I have not resigned myself to perpetual spinsterhood, though it is actually a great life like this. I am still willing to show myself the best I can, and see if anyone out there resonates. I am learning and growing around how to be even more courageous in the process of doing this, and how to more effectively show you who I am. 


The growth process and the chance I may actually connect with someone who seems to be similar to me, keep me on this platform, despite not having much luck with it, since I joined in March 2024. 


â€¦.


I will start by saying depth, authenticity, freedom, detail, precision, and embodiment are very important to me. If they are not important to you, this may be a way we are already mismatched. You may find me kind of off-putting or annoying if you want a one-page sheet that sums up who I am and what I want. 


I am not ever going to be a one-pager type of woman. 


Secondly, I would love it if you also related to life in this way. I want to know you seek a level of depth, thoroughness, and integrity in understanding yourself and how to express and embody who you are in the world, to the degree that I do, or more! 


I am a flawed human, with my own insecurities, just like we all are. I have ways I keep failing at certain goals. I am a work in progress. I am very aware of the work, every day. I have learned to have more fun with it all, in the past several years. I suppose I have been accused of being an over-thinker or a person who is too serious. I do reflect and consider many realities, throughout each day. I can also be very serious. But, I am also a playful, silly, fun person, too. I just donâ€™t tend to immediately come off that way, in certain contexts. My conscientiousness or thoughtfulness can be written off as tedious, when I am just trying to show care and love for others. 


I do tend to be most playful when I am around people I feel comfortable with. I also tend to shine brightest, when I am working, out in nature, being spontaneous, dancing, enjoying a sensual sexual experience, eating my favorite foods, surfing, doing pole, on adventures, and traveling. I shine the brightest during solo travel, though I want to travel with a partner. I long for this.


I am a really complex person. I think I could spend a whole lifetime revealing who I am to someone. I put great effort into sharing who I am and want to be seen. I also expect the person wants to know all these parts of me, just the way I want to know all of them. I deeply desire to have the type of relationship where we delight in learning more and more about each other, and rest into a deeper and deeper knowing of the otherâ€™s spirit. 


You will find in me a deeply loyal and committed partner. Someone who wants to take the time to understand and connect with you. I will always push myself to overcome fear and shame, in order to not hide or protect myself, with you. I just need to see you are a safe person to do this with. I want to be met in this way by another. Letâ€™s create a level of safety with each other that we have never encountered, anywhere, through mutually delving deep within and choosing to be accountable, self-loving, and available to each other, every day. 


I am also an extremely generous person. I want to give the people I love (friends and partners) everything I can. I am big on making and giving gifts. I am big on doting on people. I love creating an atmosphere of abundance together with people. I want us to be so open and fluid in our generosity with each other, that we love treating one another to things. I want to create that sort of atmosphere, where we treat each other like royalty. I want to have you know how deeply special and valued you are to me, just like I deeply long for being treated this way by you. I donâ€™t remain connected to people anymore, who do not have this same aim in their close relationships. I want you to be my treasure, and I want to be your treasure, too. 


I would love us to create a life together based around travel and living in a way we choose. I donâ€™t want us to settle in life. I want us to both be clear of what we want, and aim for that. I want us to support each other in developing our individual paths to the highest degree, and to live a fulfilling, authentic life. This may mean doing homeschool for our kids, or living in a very unique way together. This may mean developing an open relationship. This may mean eventually being Poly. This may mean us having periods of time where we are traveling without each other or living separately. I have a lot of flexibility in terms of how we can live our best lives that deeply honor who we are as individuals, all held within the love, trust, safety, and commitment we have with each other. I want a strong enough â€œWEâ€, so we can also keep supporting full freedom of the â€œIâ€, and vice versa. 


I am a dreamer, but I am also a pragmatist. Naturally, everything I envision with a life partner, is something I have built towards cultivating with them. As I am already living this way, myself. 


I realized at a pretty early age that if I didnâ€™t get right with myself, I would not be very happy or successful in the world. 


So, I use every opportunity I can to grow and transform. I have done a ton of work on myself (and continue to do so) in order to be the most free, courageous, accountantable, autonomous and capable human I can be. 


I live nomadically. I have created a job where I have the freedom and the amount of time to travel and play around the world. I am working on becoming even more free and rich in time and resources. I am working on living my life only doing what I want to do, when I want to do it. It has required a lot of planning and failure, but I am getting there, more and more.


I am also living a life where I am doing the exact work I want to be doing. It feels deeply meaningful, and is very rewarding. So, I get the honor of having my work be a naturally authentic expression of who I am and how I want to be in the world. 


I have also done a lot of healing work on myself. I have gone to trauma therapy, learned all about and healed a ton of my trauma (still working on it), and I deeply understand my strengths and weaknesses. I have become an exquisite communicator precisely because of all the healing work I have done, and the opportunities I take to practice showing up better as a human, every day. My heart is open, most of the time, and when it is not, I do my best to understand why, to share openly about this, and to overcome my fear and shame. 


I have created a community of people around the world where we have a supportive relationship, who see me and know me deeply, who are not scared to call me out and help me see my blind spots. I do the same for them! This is exactly how I want it! 


I am currently working on a larger goal of moving to Italy. I will likely move there in April or May 2025. I do not plan to move back to the US. I am from Hawaii originally, and lived in Colorado and Northern California for a while, before moving to Mexico in 2017. I have been using Mexico as my home base ever since. Soon, Italy will be my home base as I travel around and explore more of this amazing planet. 


With or without you, my life will be great. I would prefer to do it with you. I would love to embark on the adventure of life partnership and family, done in a creative and unique way, that preserves and expresses the wildness in us.


Are you interested? Have you built a life that involves this level of courage, adventure, accountability, authenticity, growth, joy, and creativity? If so, reach out to me. I would love to connect with you.


Reach out via email: 


apommerenk@gmail.com

The muse generates the ideas, the prophet has the patience to write them down. Just donâ€™t let the muse â€“ different, fascinating â€“ take away all your energy. Is your partner dominant or submissive?â€
â€œDominant, but not in the sense of controlling. Butâ€¦â€
â€œkindling a flame.â€
Song quotes
Spotify playlist
"It's a whole new place with a brand new attitude, but you still gotta catch 'em all and be the best you can be." (Pokemon Johto)
"I'll fly until the end of the sky, so I'll be the one who doesn't have to say goodbye." (Rainbow Dash, in Iâ€™ll Fly)
"Your love makes me see things so clearly" (Anna Rose, Vienna Teng)
"I used to make myself believe that planet earth turns slowly when I'm asleep" (Fireflies, Owl City)
"Am I human or am I dancer?" (Human, The Killers)
"I don't know my purpose in this, but it's obvious it's minuscule at best." (Time Bending, Loquat)
"Sadness is a blessing" (Lykke Li)
"And the less I seek my source for some definitive, the closer I am to fine" (Closer to Fine, Indigo Girls)
"They were kids that I once knew Now they're all dead hearts to you" (Dead Hearts, Stars)
â€œOpen up your window shades and illuminateâ€ (Illuminate, Afrojack)
â€œI hope you find the love that's true So the morning light can shine on youâ€ (Shine, Benjamin Francis Leftwich)
â€œHold on when you give love, let go when you give itâ€ (Stars)
â€œJust leave me your stardust to remember you byâ€ (Boats & Birds, Gregory and the Hawk)
â€œCome down now, they'll say. But everything looks perfect from far awayâ€ (Such Great Heights, The Postal Service)
â€œEven if the dreams I had turned into dust There's no wreckage that's too broken to rebuildâ€ (Braver still, JJ Heller)
"What does it take to make our dreams collide, The smallest change can make you feel alive." (Here We Go, WILD)
â€œWe caught bugs and frogs and feelings. â€˜Wait did i just say that? Sorry!â€™ â€˜Yeah you should be! We caught bugs and toads and feelings!â€ (At The Cemetery, Madilyn Mei)
Quotes
"Back when she was afraid of the dark she always brought a flashlight. But it turned out that was exactly why she was afraid. The whole world was black and she was a shining target." (Saskiad, Brian Hall)
â€œIf we do not suffer with our pain, then we have not learned about anything but ourselves. Pain without suffering is like victory without struggle.â€ (Shantaram, Gregory David Roberts)
â€œwhen there is love, the widowed must stay for the resurrection of the beloved - so that the one who has gone is not really dead, but grows and is created for a second time in the soul of the living.â€ (The Heart is a Lonely Hunter, Carson McCullers)
"A certain type of perfection can only be realized through a limitless accumulation of the imperfect." (Kafka on the Shore, Haruki Murakami)
"If a man will begin with certainties, he shall end in doubts; but if he will be content to begin with doubts, he shall end in certainties." (Francis Bacon)
"I guess we all like to be recognized not for one piece of fireworks but for the ledger of our daily work." (Neil Armstrong)

About me

ALT
Iâ€™m a co-founder of Impact Academy - a non-profit that runs ambitious educational programs to enable young people to use their careers to solve some of the most pressing problems and contribute to a better future. I also work as a coach for impact-driven people. I enjoy communal living and have lived in multiple group houses -  including one with a six-month-old baby, but am also open to other forms of communal living.
Before that, I did a bunch of different things throughout my life. I trained as a medical doctor, did biosecurity research at Stanford that might have contributed a tiny bit to the prevention of pandemics, co-founded Effective Altruism Denmark, co-authored a book during my undergrad, and created a course for 1000+ students.
Iâ€™m also a mediocre salsa dancer and a non-terrible singer (who loves to sing Alicia Keys songs). On the more adventurous side, I've spent four months in Nepal and hitchhiked from Copenhagen to Budapest.
My journey
Due to luck and a great teacher, I had a wake-up call when I was 16 and I realized that I was on a bad trajectory. I started to work on forming my values, character, and lifestyle to take care of myself and lead a more meaningful and altruistic life (such as supporting refugees). As I was deciding on my degree, I considered many different options (from social science to philosophy) as Iâ€™m very curious (and still am! ðŸ™‚). However, I narrowed it down to medicine and psychology and eventually decided on medicine as I thought it was the most promising way of understanding the human condition and thus help others the most. Especially those who needed it the most. This was mainly driven by altruism, curiosity, and unnoticed guilt.
During the first years of my undergrad, I co-authored aÂ bookÂ with a Norwegian author who had inspired me when I was younger. The book we wrote together was on how to study effectively and I was later hired to create and teach a course for all medical students at my university. I eventually decided to pivot away from this because I believed effective altruism and global health were more important (not an easy decision!). I had several existential crises and almost dropped out to join Effective Giving when it was starting out. However, I decided to finish the degree and build the EA community in Denmark (which I did for three years next to med school). During these later years, I also started finding â€œmy people,â€ with whom I built deep friendships that last to this day, frequently bringing me joy and gratitude.
Towards the end of med school, I ran a career experiment in biosecurity at Stanford University, SSI, and the US CDC for two years. My research was on mortality monitoring usingÂ EuroMOMOÂ because I predicted itâ€™d be useful in pandemics (pre-covid). This included living in an incredible group house with entrepreneurs in Palo Alto and trying coaching. These experiences introduced me more seriously to entrepreneurship and coaching - both of which Iâ€™ve been pursuing since 2020. In 2022, I had the fortune of meeting some awesome and like-minded people who had a similar vision so we co-founded Impact Academy.
Me facilitating a workshop at a conference. (2019)
ALT
My decade vision
I have three main ambitions for this decade (until December 31st, 2030):
Make Impact Academy a world-class organization that runs ambitious educational programs to enable people to use their careers to solve some of the most pressing problems and contribute to a better future.
Find the other half of an altruistic couple - a "romantic co-founder". Someone who wants to co-create a beautiful relationship where we can support each other in our missions to create a better world, grow, and create beautiful experiences. This could involve starting a family.
Be a coach for some of the most impactful individuals and enable them to enhance their lifetime impact, become their best selves, and care for themselves and their loved ones.

For several years, I wanted to adopt, but now I think that isnâ€™t the best way to improve the world. Recently, that shifted for me and if I find a partner, Iâ€™m open to it (but not in the next two years) if it doesnâ€™t significantly detract from our ability to serve the world.

Agnostic/atheist: Iâ€™m deeply grateful for the scientific method and the Scout Mindset. You might be somewhat religious or spiritual, but youâ€™re more likely to identify as Atheist or Agnostic. About you
Below is my current hypothesis for what Iâ€™m looking for in a partner. If most of this resonates, then we might be a great match, though (in all honesty) you may be too good for me. ðŸ˜Š Donâ€™t worry about â€œticking all of the boxesâ€ - the most important thing is that most of these resonate with you. Iâ€™d much rather that you err in favor of reaching out (youâ€™re probably awesome) than think that you â€œdonâ€™t tick enough boxesâ€.
Qualities and tendencies
Important stuff
We will likely be a good match if most of the following qualities are important to you.
Ethical and on an ambitious mission to make the world better.
You have a drive to make the world a better place and have used this as your guiding star during most of your important life decisions. You have engaged with several moral theories, and you likely find some form of consequentialism the most plausible, though you appreciate other theories. You might be particularly devoted to the betterment of future generations or think that the alleviation of suffering is more important than the promotion of happiness. Youâ€™ve probably been inspired by Effective Altruism (though may have significant reservations), but youâ€™re at least positive about the core principles of wanting to improve the world and using reason and evidence.
Intellectual and curious.
You find great joy in understanding things by using a scientific mindset. Holding accurate beliefs is much more important than being right to you. Youâ€™ve changed your mind on important issues, which led to you taking action, too. Even though it was weird or unconventional. You enjoy trying new things, are likely an avid reader, and find long (3 hours+) conversations enjoyable.
Growth-oriented and perhaps even a bit wise.
Growing as a person and becoming wiser is important to you. For many years, youâ€™ve probably done things such as i) reflecting on your values, strengths, and weaknesses, ii) trying to optimize/systematize your life, and iii) cultivating virtues such as humility and kindness. You may have read books like Manâ€™s Search For Meaning, The Seven Habits of Highly Effective People, and Peak and have habits like meditation, journaling, and tracking. You probably also love facilitating this for others.
Globally-minded (Cosmopolitan)
Youâ€™re globally minded and care about global affairs - from the more substantive and difficult to the lighthearted. For example, youâ€™ll happily engage in a discussion on the relationship between the US and China and appreciate cultivating friendships with people from different cultures.
Loving and affectionate yet strong and emotionally stable
Youâ€™re caring and attentive to the needs of others. Youâ€™d sense whether Iâ€™m happy or sad and make me feel cared for via your words and actions (and emojis â˜ºï¸). Bonus points if one of your love languages is physical touch. That being said, you have a fairly deep sense of who you are and some level of self-compassion. Consequently, you donâ€™t let othersâ€™ perspectives and needs crowd out yours so you can set boundaries and express disagreements when you think itâ€™s right.
Professionally, youâ€™re likely to have tried many different things that involved bringing out the best in people and were deeply guided by the things above. Youâ€™re passionate and (at least mildly) obsessive about what you do. Perhaps you are (or have been):

Past relationships
Iâ€™m grateful for the previous romantic relationships Iâ€™ve been part of, and I think all of them are wonderful people. However, they didnâ€™t work for some important reasons, and itâ€™s valuable to learn from them. Here are some reasons why it didnâ€™t work (work in progress).

Not enough altruism and/or dedication.

.

in Seattle, where I studied Computer Science. I didn't really like Seattle. The weather was too dreary, and I found the people standoffish. That said, I don't think there's anywhere in the world more beautiful than Seattle in the summertime.

travel
.
I always feel like I haven't done enough of it. New York City is home right now (and the best city), but San Francisco is the center of my world (both personally and professionally), and my heart is in Tel Aviv. my website
.
