I support social safety nets, universal health care, and regulation against anti-competitive business practices. I love America; it's not without its faults, but I love how it enables class mobility, supports entrepreneurship, and fosters unparalled diversity.
I'm an avid reader.
I enjoy reading everything from contemporary fiction, to German literature, to dense biographies, to research papers, to popsci, and everything in between. I used to read 50+ books a year, but now it's closer to one every other week.
I live an active life.
I exercise almost every day, usually for about an hour. I enjoy weightlifting for fitness and as a sort of meditative activity. For recovery, I've been getting into yoga. For cardio, I try to run or erg 2-3x a week. As trite as it sounds, I really like walking, and try to get in at least 15k steps per day. I also enjoy hiking and snowboarding, but don't get to do either nearly enough.
I try to eat well,
but don't follow a strict diet. At one point I followed a ketogenic diet, but I found that obsessing about carbs was itself unhealthy, and, more importantly, it made me unhappy. Being flexible about what I eat is one of my greatest joys â€” I love trying new foods and cuisines without much consideration for ingredients. That said, I do my best to avoid processed and fast foods.

Hallo, hallo. This is K speaking.
(I'll tell you my name later, of course. Even my shoe size. Just not sure how this 'going public with loads of seriously personal' works yet...)
I'd like to start with some controversies, if I may - they should tickle your interest buds, all being well.
And there you go, the first one has just
landed
, and even without intent!
I make up phrases in English sometimes, quite probably because it is my second language. But aren't your interest buds all the merrier now that they know they exist?!
For illustration
(
though, a non-linguistic one
):
photographic evidence of the moment when my nephew and I invented the 'simultaneous reverse swing selfie' 10 years ago.
(I've made the whole sorcery into a 12" video but this site wouldn't... so this is the end frame, as you can tell from the catharsis on our faces.)
alrighty then, on with the controversies...
I love hiking
but hate camping
these two loonies
I wasn't supposed to befriend because
I am allergic to dogs
but I've walked them for a friend with the greatest joy dozens of times
best sound and smell!
aaand I am allergic to dust ðŸ˜©
I'm creative (in some ways)
and while you might not get the sense instantly, I'll have you know that I've just done an online test and it says it is one of my signature strengths, OK?!
time to get back to the allergies...
I love dogs, horses and cats are OK, too, but if you have any of these living in your house, we'd be in a pickle...
But hey, don't write me down as 'the allergy girl'! I might be lactose intolerant and vegetarian, too, but no hayfever can sweep me off my feet!
Jokes aside (hope you've been having the time of your life so far), I'm a heterosexual female, 178 cm tall and 60 kg, give or take, and an atheist. I turned 40 three months ago, which feels so recent, but if you think about it, that's one Q already... ðŸ˜¶
I live in London normally (but presently unemployed so sticking it out in a cheaper place) but if a job offer took me to Copenhagen, Stockholm or Amsterdam by any chance, I wouldn't weep my eyes out. (I love bikes and definitely prefer cycling to public transport... but not just for the bike culture, of course!)
I work in project management in the creative industries but I've just completed a short course in environmental sustainability and oh my, there's just so much potential in so many areas of sustainable development! I firmly believe that if anything, technology and science will save humanity from exterminating this planet but there's so much everyone can do! I hope you agree with that and don't let climate despair get the better of you!
I hate waste in any of its forms (materials, time, money, energy....). I wish I had the skills of a chemical engineer to invent more ways to upcycle/recycle waste. Or the powers of a social psychologist to ignite a grassroots movement that would turn overconsumption into something society would end up frowning upon and would eventually lead to global behavioural change... (My folks call me naive at least once a fortnight so it's OK if you think I'm a bit too far into wishful thinking, don't worry.)
Lacking the skills of scientists, though, at least I have a skeleton idea of a dark comedy tv show (in terms of flavour, think of a layered cake of Boat Story, Back to Life, After Life, and, me, of course) that would stick it into the faces of local governments (and the main one) re how much more they could actually do (or try to do) to solve/ease a bunch of social and environmental issues at local levels. We'd be following the stumblings of a 40-something main character who is completely lost on the tracks of self-development (but sane, just kind of driftwood-ish a bit), and circumstances make him/her settle into a small town community, and we watch in awe how these stumblings sometimes turn into brilliant solutions to problems without the main character's slightest awareness of his/her role in them... anyway, I could go on but you'd need to sign an NDA. However, if you have any ties to Two Brothers Pictures or Harry Williams or Jack Williams (the two brothers) or their EAs or their PAs or their postman, get in touch this instant, of course! (Ricky Gervais' management agency I had tried already, the most junior of their junior staff bounced me off in a blink of an eye, albeit, politely ðŸ™‚ )
But yeah, if not changing the perception of the population about overconsumption and overproduction, there are still a billion things to try, right?! I did some decluttering a couple of months ago, took crates of items to a market with the intent of donating the proceeds to animal shelters. Luckily, I managed to sell a dozen items or so. Then winter came, the books got soaked right after unpacking one time so I took the whole thing online. I created a website, photographed hundreds of clothes, books, utensils, knick-knacks, and spent ages uploading and describing everything and getting word out on local social media... then 3 books and a cheesegrater got bought. But hey, the intent was there!
Dreaming of having a small abode right by a lake
This spot is my favourite so far but I'm happy to go for an old Scandinavian villa on sale for peanuts with you, to do up while I can swim a lot and make lots of hot beverages for us. Or a Mediterranean little house? With colder drinks?
Are you also scanning social media channels like cheappropertyeurope and such daily? (Ours will have solar panels and a heat pump and all the clever things, OK?)
I asked a friend to describe me as this seems to be a frequent advice re dating profiles... so this is from her (and I am all blushing while typing):
A clever introvert with such integrity but little confidence.
She values tranquility over fanfare but she is all in for adventures and creating memorable experiences.
Keeps lots of her ideas to herself despite being a creative person, possibly due to being afraid (that lack of confidence thing...).
Intelligent, great sense of humour, quick on the uptake but a bit sceptical first about new things. Sometimes it takes a bit of letting guards down but after that she is a truly loyal, trustworthy friend, by your side through thick and thin.
She is monogamous and would go for problem-solving without hesitation rather than throwing it all in way too soon. She expects honesty and loyalty in return as well: once trust is gone, it would be a rocky road winning it back.
The person who will fall for her (who will seriously want to make her happy) will get a most devoted wingman (woman), that's for sure. And the two of them will carry around laughing their heads off, probably. She is such fun when there's no need for walls.
There. Can you believe all that praise?!
Embarrassingly
lovely, isn't she? But she has known me since I was about 3 years old so... ðŸ˜¬
And you know me a little by now, too, don"t you? - let's get pragmatic and avoid wasting each other's time (if that's the case) because wasting is so insanely stupid.
I guess this aversion to waste accounts for my thriftiness and indecisiveness. For me it takes longer to decide on a purchase or an action plan than for most people - and if you are the kind of clever guy I'm after, it might have already clicked for you that what I'm trying to do with the best intentions is just another form of wasting, i.e. wasting time under the illusion that I'm working out the optimal usage of resources.... ðŸ™ƒÂ  how dumb, huh?! If you'd found me out, get in touch by all means. I could definitely welcome someone in my life who catches me out when I should be. And the best would be if you were patient and easy-going, too. Or just patient.
I don't seem to be attracted to men with long hair and I am not keen on facial hair, either (I have a theory that circa 98.7% of men sporting a beard or a moustache would look incomparably more handsome without them. There's such a tiny segment of the male population who might actually benefit from growing facial hair that I could almost elevate this theory into a general rule. But I won't, cause I respect the rights of those 1,214 men to attractiveness.).
I prefer not being taller, stronger, faster, fitter or heavier than my man.
I'm not planning on having kids so it would be great if you didn't have/want any, either.
I guess I am just writing this whole novella because I wonder if there's a chance after you have already lived half of your life to find someone who can add kindness and smiles to the remaining years while you want to add the same to theirs because you both understand how precious companionship actually is. Just looking for a team mate (whom I quite fancy), I reckon.
You don't need to be a dashing prince with wealth or have a great sense of style but as long as your sense of humour is ace and you like to fool around while also being aware that no relationship can get far without respect or honesty and that maintenance on it will most probably be needed along the way, too, we could be in for something.
Be old enough to know that you carry the responsibility for all you do and say but young enough to still want to venture out there and enjoy tomfoolery. (38-46 would cover that, you think?)
birthday present
loved it! (I mean, I didn't get the plane...)
good to become friends
with strangers who bring your food
didn't get this aircraft, either
but maaan, holding out your phone on a trike for a photo when there's absolutely nothing underneath is a thrill!
a full body shot
is probably also expected... Serious face was art director's doing. Location global fashion giant's choice.

half-finished projects, as well as some finished ones
.

,
Matt Levine on finance
,
Chemical Safety Board investigations
,

I enjoy being out in nature, and I ride my bike along the Bay Trail on weekends. I like road trips, and my friends and I usually go on a road trip every winter. I kinda want to travel abroad more, but I'm not a fan of long plane flights.

Most surreal childhood memory: Eating at Mars 2112 - an immersive Mars-themed restaurant set up to look like it was carved out of red rock! It had everything - people in alien costumes, a spaceship ride, and above-average chicken fingers. It was emblematic of the kind of early 2000s decadence that we may never see again.
TV triumph that I most often think about: The series finale of Nathan for You.
TV disappointment that I most often think about: The series finale of Lost.
Top podcasts: Normal Gossip, Maintenance Phase, Criminal, You're Wrong About, 5-4, Serious Trouble.
If money were not a concern: When I first got into programming in high school it was because I wanted to make games, but it turns out that the game industry is horrible and abusive and pays terribly, so I'd much rather be ensconced in a cushy tech jobâ€¦ anyway all of that is to say that if I didn't have to worry about money then I'd totally start my own game studio (that pays people well and is not abusive).
Relationship to games: I wish there was a word to describe someone who likes video games but whose life isn't spiraling out of control due to a video game addiction. In any caseâ€¦ that's me! I love games, and I love in particular thinking about what makes them tick. I prefer a broad mix of games and usually don't stick with one for long. Some of my favorites are Baba is You, Breath of the Wild, Oxygen Not Included, Disco Elysium, Inscription, Tunic, and Kentucky Route Zero.
"He sounds great but is he a crypto/NFT guy?": Lol no.
"He sounds great but is he a fan of Joe Rogan or Andrew Tate or Elon Musk? Or is he some other kind of right-wing sicko?": Absolutely not!
Contacts: hello.there.msh@gmail.com

About me
Hello! Iâ€™m Lawrence. Here youâ€™ll find some basics about me, what Iâ€™m looking for in a relationship, and some of my writing and photos.


Basics:
* I'm a 29-year-old straight cis man and 6â€™3â€. 
* I live in Berkeley, CA, but Iâ€™m not super attached to the Bay Area and I like traveling.
* Looking for a long- or medium-term relationship, open to dating both trans and cis women. 
* I donâ€™t know if I want kids. 
* Iâ€™m open to both polyamorous and monogamous relationships. 
What my friends say about me
â€œLawrence is pretty emotionally mature and insightful in a bunch of ways, and is happy to talk about feelings. [..] I think he might be the best person I know for helping people get over lack of intellectual self-confidence and problems with being intimidated by technical content. [..] He holds himself to very high standards, in a way that can sometimes hurt him but is also often very positive â€“ heâ€™s extremely receptive to feedback and is very non-defensive even when heâ€™s upset. I think heâ€™d be a good match for someone who wants their relationship to be a big source of growth and improvement, but also of security and unconditional affection.â€ 
â€“ Beth Barnes


â€œMan Lawrence, if you have romantic struggles, then there's no hope for the rest of us.â€  
â€“ Nat Kozak
More about me 
I often feel intense emotions. I sometimes stop while walking or driving to just take in the view and reflect on how good things are. I get excited about clever ideas and am deeply touched by acts of kindness. I feel on a deep level that most people are very good and are trying their best, and it makes me really sad when they fail or have a rough time. I feel very upset when people are unreasonable, and I often feel a strong desire to fix problems I see around me.


I have a pretty good memory. Both for dates and conversations, and for lots of random facts.


Iâ€™m eager to pick up my partnerâ€™s interests. In the past, Iâ€™ve enjoyed ballroom dancing, traveling, hiking, cooking together, stargazing, and visiting museums and exhibits. I enjoy talking about machine learning, economics, history, psychology, and random animal facts.
  

I have a dog. His name is Benji, and heâ€™s a good boy (not really, but he is a very adorable one). 


I care deeply about doing good. I want to make both the world around me and the world in general a better place. Iâ€™ll stand up for what I think is right, and try to keep promises and be fair to people. (Also, sometimes I stay up all night to help others finish their projects and meet their deadlines.)
Who I tend to get along with
Sincerity and kindness: I like people who say true things, genuinely relate to others, and arenâ€™t afraid to wear their heart on their sleeve. I like people who do nice things for others from the depths of their hearts. Also, I think itâ€™s fine to take lots of time and be very gentle when you do it, but I think itâ€™s very important to be able to face hard truths about yourself or the world.


Intellectual curiosity: I like having conversations with a partner where I feel like one or more of us are learning something, or I can share in their enthusiasm and knowledge about a subject. 


High standards: I like people who have high standards and push themselves and their partners to grow and improve.
Possible sources of incompatibility
I can be quite negative. When Iâ€™m sad, I often feel like nothing is working; when I fail, I can be quite harsh with myself. I also tend to be lower valence in general, but Iâ€™m working on being gentler and happier. I sometimes express true but unkind opinions about others. 


I work a lot. I think itâ€™s important to be working on productive things, so I tend to be a bit of a homebody by default and Iâ€™m not likely to spontaneously develop new hobbies. However, I think that spending time with my partner would definitely count as productive time and Iâ€™m happy to spend a lot of time with you!


I donâ€™t drink or do drugs. I feel comfortable hanging out with people who drink, though I would feel uncomfortable about frequent heavy drinking. Iâ€™m also fine with psychedelics as long as you donâ€™t take them in the presence of charismatic cult leaders. 


I am pretty attached to my dog. If youâ€™re allergic to dogs, this will be a problem. Sorry. 
________________
Other Pictures
  
  
  

Contact Info
If youâ€™re interested in chatting more or think weâ€™re compatible, please email me at lawrencechan96@gmail.com. 
________________
Appendix
Some things I believe about dating docs and dating:
Dating docs arenâ€™t (just) for finding dates. I think a significant fraction of the value of dating docs comes from the process of writing; another large fraction comes from communicating information with future partners that might not come up naturally in the first few dates. Iâ€™m also not super convinced that dating docs work well for finding new people to date, compared to e.g. asking people out in person. So this doc errs on the side of being more informative as opposed to promotional. 


Emotional and social intelligence are real and important. There are many skills in actually making relationships work, both in terms of knowing yourself and in terms of knowing how to relate to others. While I can be a fan of numbers and spreadsheets, itâ€™s important to be in touch with who you are and what you want, and also who your partner is and what they want. Also, communication is important! 


Shared interests are significantly less important than shared values and shared desire to make a relationship work. I think dating apps and docs tend to focus too much on screening for shared interests or experiences, which I think can easily be developed over time. (In particular, Iâ€™m happy to pick up your interests! In the past Iâ€™ve picked up the interests of previous partners.) On the other hand, deeply held values are probably unlikely to change, and I donâ€™t think romantic relationships work without both parties wanting it to work and putting in the effort.


Most disagreements and issues can be worked through (given shared values and a desire to make the relationship work). I think I have a lot of growth mindset for relationships; I think that many common points of disagreement can be worked on. For example, I think that issues like division of labor (for chores) or different hobbies can generally be solved if both people are willing to try. As a corollary, I think that fights are really bad in romantic relationships; the whole point is to be on the same side, and work toward a mutual goal. Accordingly, Iâ€™ve had very few fights in my past romantic relationships. 


Security is necessary for people to grow in relationships. I personally value relationships that push me to grow and do better, but I donâ€™t think these relationships can be stable without a firm bedrock of security and mutual trust. After all, itâ€™s pretty hard to be ambitious if you feel like a single misstep could cause your partner to leave you.


Relationships can be thought of as trade agreements, but you generally shouldnâ€™t. Relationships are trade agreements (in the sense that every persistent interaction can be thought of as a trade agreement), and this frame can be somewhat helpful. For example, it highlights the fact that relationships should be a positive sum voluntary endeavor, and that both partners should try to provide things that are to their comparative advantage. However, I find that this framing can often cause people to take an adversarial stance toward their partners (i.e. a trade negotiation), or cause people to value tangible, concrete things about their partners over emotional support or vibes, and so donâ€™t think that people should think about relationships this way by default. 


Additional writing samples:
I guess the largest repository my public writing is my LessWrong account: https://www.lesswrong.com/users/lawrencec

Testimonials:
â€œManic pixie dream girl who makes you more normalâ€

Honestly my Twitter probably tells you more about me than this does: @WillowChem
Hi! I'm Anna Crow/Anna Magpie, haven't settled on that yet, a 23-year-old trans woman living in the United Kingdom.
As of writing this (1:17am BST, September 5th 2024) I am in the process of attempting to independently fundraise my salary so I can go to Stanford and run a longitudinal study monitoring tens of thousands of different biomarkers on people beginning, then throughout gender affirming hormone therapy, in order to begin to develop a foundational understanding of how to coordinate complex signaling pathways in real world biological systems.
I am
currently applying to computational biology PhDs mostly in/around London. My core interest is in understanding biology â€œacross scalesâ€. How do we integrate molecular biology data into a coherent whole in order to make useful predictions about disease, with a particular focus on aging. A subquestion I find particularly interesting is the extent to which regulatory networks are defined by complex, non-linear interactions vs simple additive ones. This question has big implications for combination therapies and, more generally, how fast we should expect biomedicine to progress.
M
y life is a little up in the air at the moment, I'm currently staying at CEEALAR, but hopefully moving to London sooner rather than later.
Polyamorous by default. I want to have one or two people that I'm extremely special to, and as long as I feel special to someone I can't bring myself to care about whether they're having sex/romance with other people; monogamous relationships just sound like too much work.
Chronic infodumper, if we date, you can expect rambles on things like
Biology, especially cellular biology, the mechanisms of aging, and mathematical models of evolution. Evolution is a better engineer than you are and I will tell you exactly why
Military history, I have a particular interest in the development of early semi-automatic firearms, and how this was influenced by institutional thinking around infantry doctrine. However I'm a modern warfare geek in full generality. Also I have strong opinions about people with strong opinions about the F-35.
Aquaculture and ornamental fish. Iâ€™m a keen tropical fishkeeper, although I haven't been able to pursue this seriously lately due to the housing constraints associated with being a student.
If you also like these topics, that's great, but if not I'm probably happy to listen to you if you ramble as well.
Generally eclectic, very into HEMA (Historical fencing with an emphasis on the martial art), bouldering, hanging out in places which have neat people to talk to (hackerspaces, etc.), and photography, almost exclusively wildlife, but someday I'll get into astro (even if you don't do that part with me, it would be great if you accompanied me on the outdoor walks. You will learn about birds and you will enjoy it). I also like to read: Trying desperately to get out of the rationalist monoculture, so have picked up â€œAn experiment in criticism by CS Lewisâ€ and in the middle of â€œThe guns of Augustâ€
I have extremely strong feelings about moral responsibility and individual virtue, especially as they relate to interpersonal relationships. In general I think that the biggest distinction between me and others isnâ€™t intelligence or aptitude, I just care more. I also value serious, precise thinking and try to be fairly ruthless about avoiding what I can best term â€œvibes based analysisâ€ alongside discouraging it in others. Iâ€™ve deliberately cultivated an instinctual uneasiness about hard to falsify claims. I want to date someone who helps me to be a better thinker, a better truthseeker. In the golden light of the dawn, I head to the gymnasium, its tall, firm Corinthian columns silhouetted against the morning sun. I fall into the smooth, strong curves of my beloved Antinous, resting my head against his slender â€” yet exquisitely toned â€” chest, and drift into the embrace of the still midnight... sorry, what were you asking again?

I noticed lots of people I follow on Twitter were making these. Yes, I know itâ€™s a bit awkward to read (imagine how awkward it was to write!), but letâ€™s lean into that! I think it seems like an interesting way to share more information than is typically permitted by dating apps. 


Twitter user @chanamessinger has started a twitter thread with a number of examples, and @FerrisHueller wrote about the merits of similar documents.
tl;dr
  
  
  



Ryan McGuine


Age: 30
Height: 6â€™0â€
Gender: Male
Location: Currently Kansas City, MO
Monogamy?: Yes 
Wants kids?: Definitely, within the next 5 years 
Looking for: Eventually something serious and long-term; uninterested in aimless casual fun, but not rushing into something
About you
Not â€œrequirementsâ€, but the items below are very strong pluses for me.


Professional ambition: Not in a â€œoptimize all of life for success at workâ€ manner, but in a â€œhaving a growth mindset while doing the thing we spend most of our waking hours doing is rewardingâ€ manner. 


Physical activity: Iâ€™m physically fit, which I value both for the associated mental clarity and emotional wellbeing, as well as the ability to carry out functional tasks elsewhere in life. I prefer the same in a partner. 


Financial wellbeing: If I cloned my financial situation, I could comfortably afford a house and children. Itâ€™s not important to me that you meet or exceed my finances precisely, but would like to be building toward those things together.


Calmness and stability: You can take on practical tasks and have a reasonable ability to regulate your emotions when you get overwhelmed. I walk away from a conversation with you feeling reassured, and that we can work together to manage complicated things.


Intellectual spark: Big points for any regular habit of consuming books or audiobooks, movies, podcasts, etc. Related traits I value include curiosity, some amount of introspection, an ability to hold ideas in tension, and a sense of humor. 


Adventurous outlook: Iâ€™m looking for someone who does things. I enjoy challenging activities like spending long stretches outdoors, visiting countries with very different cultures, or attending sporting events (even in bad weather). Extrapolating slightly, life often involves some amount of discomfort, but staying on the couch is so much less memorable â€“ letâ€™s embrace the chaos and create a big life together.
About me
  
  



I am a mechanical engineer at an infrastructure construction company based in Kansas City. Iâ€™m not sure if I will do construction or live in Kansas City forever, but I enjoy the stability and work-life balance I have at the moment.  


In my free time I enjoy being physically active (lifting weights, triathlon training, and hiking, rock climbing, snowboarding) writing essays about sustainability and global development on my blog, exploring Kansas City (attending live music or sporting events, trying new bars or restaurants), spending time with friends and family, practicing the piano, and traveling. While I sometimes stay in reading or watching movies, I generally prefer doing things outside the house. 


I used to consume a lot of nonfiction explainer podcasts and YouTube videos, trying to â€œunderstandâ€ the larger world, but have gradually become more interested in fiction, as well as learning about psychology, relationships, and leadership. There is a balance to be found in news consumption â€“ while itâ€™s possible to follow events too closely for oneâ€™s own mental health, I think we have an obligation to be informed and have opinions in a democracy. 


I really think that smartphones (in particular the ability to infinitely scroll through brain rotting short video content) are terrible for us. While Iâ€™ll never get rid of mine because itâ€™s incredibly useful, I try to avoid using social media apps as little as possible. Work by Anna Lembke and Michael Easter, and to a lesser extent Jonathan Haidt did a lot to convince me. 


I consider myself somewhat religious. I grew up Catholic and attend Mass sporadically, but aspire to be more regular. I find Catholicism comforting since I grew up in it, and resonate with the idea of a monotheistic God, but suspect that if I was born in a different tradition I would practice that. Iâ€™m open-minded to people of different religions, as well as people who consider themselves agnostic. 


Iâ€™m not in a hurry to start a family immediately, but am certain that it is something I want to do within the next 5 years. At the moment, I am focusing on my trajectory (career, social life, and being active). Eventually I hope to have a financial base solid enough to simultaneously continue saving for my retirement, travel regularly, travel regularly, save for childrensâ€™ college funds, and maintain a decent standard of living.


Russ Roberts suggests using â€œsomeone youâ€™d like to visit Rome withâ€ as one filter for deciding who to marry. If I were to visit Rome, I would like to visit important buildings of ancient Rome, see some art museums, and enjoy Italian food and wine, and build in time to walk without a specific destination. More important than specific activities, Iâ€™d like to be joined by someone who could help me discover all the city has to offer â€“ someone who wants to be curious about it all while helping me find different ways to appreciate it, and reminisce with me about the experience afterward.         


My parents remain happily married. Having divorced parents is not a red flag, but having examples of loving adults somewhere in your life is definitely a green flag. No two relationships are identical, but all happy families have similarities, or whatever that Tolstoy quote is. I aspire to be an active participant raising kids while they live at home, and remain connected to my wife after they move out.
What next?
If this sounds interesting: fill out this form to go on a date some time, or send me a Twitter DM!


Just reach out, or get a mutual friend to introduce us! My threshold for first dates is fairly low- I'd rather test the chemistry quickly than spend lots of time texting.


I want a serious partner in the long term, but no pressure! If we hit it off but not romantically, I'm glad to be friends as well.

ï»¿I am 24 years old, cis female, 5â€™6â€ and 145 pounds.


I am looking for a relationship with deep emotional intimacy, lots of time spent together, and a view to living together and spending years in a committed relationship. I am open to such a relationship having romantic and/or sexual elements; however, I donâ€™t really experience sexual and romantic attraction, at least in the way it has been described to me by others. I do find some people more physically attractive than others and am more open to having romantic or sexual relationships with those people, but sex and romance are optional for me and I donâ€™t experience anything like crushes or a sex drive. Relatedly, I have pretty restrictive boundaries around sexual activities in particular and typically want to do them infrequently. Iâ€™m not going to give more details on my preferences here just to avoid a TMI situation, but if this might be a deal breaker for you feel free to ask me about it whenever you feel comfortable doing so.


Given my ace/aro spectrum status, and the fact that I experience next to no romantic jealousy, I would be happy for my partner to have other romantic and sexual relationships. 


Activities I would enjoy doing with you include dancing, singing, cuddling, improv comedy, deep conversations on philosophy and psychology, watching crime dramas and sitcoms (My favorites are Community and Better Call Saul), going for nature walks, going camping, going to the beach, traveling in India or Europe, and trying new and unusual things.


I have taken the Giving What We Can pledge and I currently help organize the local Portland EA and rationality group which I founded back in 2015. I am currently unemployed but would like to work in animal welfare in some capacity once my mental health and motivation improve.


I suffer from mild anxiety, low motivation (and occasionally other depressive symptoms for months at a time), and addictive tendencies (I am currently trying to get clean from kratom but am struggling and have repeatedly relapsed). I am on the autism spectrum (have you noticed?). I am extroverted, agreeable, and tend to have very low-conflict relationships. I have only ever been in one long term relationship which was very fulfilling and ended agreeably due to mental health issues on the part of my partner.


I enjoy having conversations on politics and philosophy. My politics are fairly centrist with some left-wing and some right-wing opinions on individual issues. I am very open to having relationships with people that have very different political opinions to me. My moral philosophy is something like moral anti-realist utilitarianism with an acknowledgement that my true values (as revealed by my actions) are many and my moral intuitions will never fully conform to an internally consistent system.


I am not particularly interested in marriage as I see a lifetime commitment as being unrealistic. I would however be open to having children together a little ways down the line, especially if you can support me taking 5+ years off of work to care for them. If we did have children I would want to make a strong commitment to staying together as long as doing so would be better for the children than splitting up, and if marriage is important to you as a symbol of that commitment I would be open to it. I am also open to not having children.


I am open to starting with a long distance relationship while Iâ€™m in Portland and would consider moving to nearly any large city, assuming I am able to work remotely (bay area would be preferable if I canâ€™t). I would greatly prefer one with an active EA community, but would consider a place without one for the right person. I would enjoy living alone with my partner or in a group house with likeminded people.


I think I would benefit a lot from being in a relationship with someone more conscientious than me who could encourage me to develop a greater sense of responsibility and work ethic. I like to be pushed a bit towards greater commitment to my long term goals, as long as the encouragement is positive and not shame-based.


I am open to a relationship with someone of any gender, up to 45 years old but prefer someone closer to my age (24). 


Contact me on facebook if youâ€™re interested.

As I write this, I am listening Western Klassical Music Appreciation Project (weaklap) on Twitch. The piece currently playing is Jean-Philippe Rameau - Suite in A minor/major. I don't enjoy the Baroque period too much, I feel that I am more Classical and Romantic. Modern is good but it goes too crazy sometimes. My native language is Portuguese, Brazilian portuguese. I started learning French on Duolingo for fun (387 days streak) however, Je ne parle pas franÃ§ais. I can understand Spanish but not talk. I am not a very talkative person.
I actively participate in social dances including Zouk and Forro (my culture) and more recently in Contact Improvisation and Comtemporary dance. I am interested in Microfuzion but haven't tried yet. Connecting with my own or another body is a delightful experience for me. Dance is transformative. However, no, I am not a professional dancer.


I spent a significant amount of my time developing computational approaches to analyse biological data. More specifically, studying the relatioships of epigenetic modifications and psychedelics. I am very curious and moved by an existential disquiet.

Ben's public dating profile
Hi, I'm Ben!
I spent much of my twenties dating without direction, and a
lot of my thirties focused on building my career, so I've not met the love
of my life yet. I made this page to help change that.
The basics
I'm 42, 6'4", and date women. I've never been
married, but I'd like to change that. No kids yet, but I very much want
them.
I'm looking for a committed relationship. I'm open to
standard monogamy or (once we've built a strong, loving foundation)
something more monogamish.
I'm ethnically Jewish (50% Ashkenazi) and love the culture, but I wasn't raised with any religion and don't practice any now.
My home is in Somerville, MA and I'm pretty planted here.
Last year, I bought a lake house with my family. We're there almost every
weekend in the summer, and it's made our already-close relationships even stronger.
I'm, uh, on the left.
Below you'll find more about my family (they're wonderful), my work (software company co-founder, now doing passion projects), my singing (barbershop quartet, symphony chorus), what I appreciate in a partner, and how to get in touch.
Bottom left (2021)
Family
I won the family lottery. It's almost certainly the best thing about my life.
I have a younger brother who lives nearby and is one of my favorite people. He's married with a young son and daughter. I knew I would enjoy being an uncle, but I'm liking it even more than expected. I almost can't talk about my niece and nephew without smiling.
My parents also live nearby. My mom is smart and warm, and my dad is ridiculously handy and protective of his people.
They're a very welcoming group. We're all excited to integrate my eventual partner into the crew.
These kids are so cute it's criminal to have to blur their faces.
Work
I'm the co-founder of
a software company
I started in 2018 with two friends. It went really well! This year, my co-founders and I put new leaders in place and stepped away from day-to-day operations.
I'm lucky enough that I don't currently need a day-job, so I spend most of my time pursuing passion projects. Lately, I've been getting rather
involved in local politics
(I recently hosted a mayoral debate in my city!) and building a community called
Fractal Boston
. Fractal is a group of friendly, ambitious people who eat dinner together every Sunday and help each other grow.
Singing
One of the things that brings me the most joy in life is singing.
I was fortunate to be raised by musical parents who encouraged me to join choruses at an early age. Thanks to them, I've been singing in some ensemble or another for ~30 years.
Currently, I sing with the Tanglewood Festival Choir, which performs with the Boston Symphony Orchestra.
Before that, I sang in a barbershop quartet for 10 years alongside my brother. I miss that group a lot and hope to start a new quartet someday.
I've had so many rich experiences in those groups, and I'd love to tell you about them in person.
But for now, here's a little glimpse of my quartet at one of our coolest gigs:
My quartet singing the National Anthem at Fenway Park. (2016)
Things I love in a partner ðŸ˜
You're emotionally warm and have nurturer energy. You have a ton of love to give, and are excited about receiving it as well (I'm very affectionate and always have been).
You think we'd be good at making each other laugh. I seem to value having a funny partner more than most. I've found it makes life
so
much more enjoyable. I love quick-wittedness and callbacks. These days, I most enjoy the comedy of Shane Gillis, Taylor Tomlinson, Mike Birbiglia, Jordan Jensen, Tom Segura, and Bo Burnham.
You're excited to start having kids in the next couple years (after dating, marriage, and at least one serious adventure).
Youâ€™re excited to start having kids in the next couple years (after dating, marriage, and at least one serious adventure).
Becoming a father is very important to me, and Iâ€™m open to a few different paths to get there â€” ideally having biological kids together, but Iâ€™d also consider options like surrogacy or adoption if thatâ€™s something we both feel good about.
You're willing to live near Boston most of the time
This is a pretty hard deal-breaker for me. I very much want to
live near my family a lot of the time. That said, if there's a part
of the world that's important to you to be in, I'm down to live
there some of the year! (Want to get away from New England winters, for example? No problem.)
Things I would be excited to do together
(Just some rough ideas. Naturally we're going to come up with our own list.)
Choose a time each week to check in and connect, and treat it as sacred.
Decide which of life's default settings we're into, and which we think we can improve on.
Start a business (Highly optional! Only if it flows).
Create the circumstances for spending lots of time with the people we love.
Pick a doubles sport and get into it.
Telepathically communicate that we're ready to leave the gathering.
Improve the societies we're a part of.
Things that might not work for you
I am socially quite liberal, but my economic views lean libertarian. I tend to think that capitalism and free markets usually (though not always!) produce better outcomes than their alternatives. I don't automatically think big businesses, corporate profits, or rich people are bad .
I'm a bit allergic to people using astrology as a truth-finding tool.
Getting in touch
If you think we might be a match, I'd love to hear from you:
ben@benorenstein.com
Please don't feel like you need to include as many details as I have here. However, I'd appreciate it if you included at least some basics and a few photos. If you have links to online presences that I can check out, that'd be great too.
I hope to hear from you soon! :)

You are seeing this because the administrator of this website has set up Anubis to protect the server against the scourge of AI companies aggressively scraping websites. This can and does cause downtime for the websites, which makes their resources inaccessible for everyone.
Anubis is a compromise. Anubis uses a Proof-of-Work scheme in the vein of Hashcash, a proposed proof-of-work scheme for reducing email spam. The idea is that at individual scales the additional load is ignorable, but at mass scraper levels it adds up and makes scraping much more expensive.
Ultimately, this is a placeholder solution so that more time can be spent on fingerprinting and identifying headless browsers (EG: via how they do font rendering) so that the challenge proof of work page doesn't need to be presented to users that are much more likely to be legitimate.
Please note that Anubis requires the use of modern JavaScript features that plugins like JShelter will disable. Please disable JShelter or other such plugins for this domain.

Of course, I donâ€™t photosynthesize outdoors continuously. I mean, I spend time indoors as well. Thereâ€™s nothing better than plumbing the depths of my brain at board games nights and trivia nights. And if I need some me-time, you can bet that Iâ€™ll be reading a book!

ï»¿Hello! Thanks for clicking a link to my date me doc ðŸ™‚


As of Oct 2, 2025, I am not currently looking for dates through this doc. That could change in the future! I am also still open to being flirted with if you happen to meet me in person âœ¨

ï»¿These laundry-list profiles are, in my view, totally beside the point and do not necessarily make for a lasting and fulfilling relationship. What I think does, and what Iâ€™d like, is someone whoâ€™d like to begin by just entering into a conversation, without a checklist of match-up criteria, just to see what might happen. Iâ€™m interested in the personâ€™s mind, how their mind works, what they have to say, what interests them and above all what they say or donâ€™t say in the moment. The thing below is an example of what I had to say at a particular moment, an hour or so ago on August 18, 2023, on a morning when... Which would then segue into whatever was going on in my life and/or mind at that moment that I felt like writing about. Iâ€™d like someone else to do the same, and then just maybe there might be a basis for something â€“ indefinable because whatever it is, will evolve and be created by how we interact, the extent to which we trust each other and sense that each otherâ€™s well being is important to us. I know this sounds kind of namby-pamby and vague, but talking about which composers I like or which books I read or what I do in my leisure time and my various careers: would that really tell anyone what they need to know? I suppose you could begin by asking yourself, What do I need to know about this person whoâ€™s posted this bizarre, possibly unreadable, probably self indulgent, surely stonewalling, and far too long poor excuse for a profile? I mean: what do I need to know in order to have a conversation with him? Or should I just take the plunge and begin talking to him and see what happens?


Response to someone elseâ€™s profile: 


I liked your profile, as profiles go. Meaning I could never write one like that, and I've been thinking a lot about what I could write, and when I have a moment and am in deep enough despair (just kidding, sort of), I might actually write and post one. But I don't really believe in them. I think people should just do what they would normally do if they met at a party or bar or wherever: Just begin talking and see what happens, which is what I hereby invite you to do. Via email at first, and then if it seems right/appropriate and the like, we can talk via a screen or you can board a plane and take a vacation in Budapest, where I live in a mega leafy neighborhood, magnificent view of the whole city from the terrace, beautiful walks and an interesting building (long story).


I am of course kidding about the vacation in Budapest, but, well, you know, you never know. And again, in my experience writing into a vacuum as I am now doing (okay, your photos, which are lovely, and the profile, which I liked) doesn't hold a candle to actual communication. One thing we could try is emailing in real time, as opposed to using a chat platform. Or we could do google meet without the screen, which I find distracting, so it would be a free phone call. Or anything else you'd like to suggest. I do have other suggestions, but I've already said enough, probably too much, being brief isn't exactly my strong point.
And as you can see there's very little profile-ish here, about my external life, because as I said, I think people should just write or say whatever they feel like writing/saying as in real life. And I really do invite you to do the same, without worrying about the impression it makes or anything like that. I've actually thought about starting a dating app which, like google docs albeit with a various differences, would encourage and enable people looking for a partner to do just that: just talk to each other, but within a particular structure that I'll elaborate on some other time, if we do end up talking to each other which I hope we do. If you have questions, you can ask, but here's what really interests me about anyone I meet, regardless of gender: how their mind works, what they think about, how interested they are in communicating, I mean passionately interested, and in communicating outside the envelope, if you see what I mean. Okay you don't: I mean just trying forms of communication other than the usual getting to know you sort of thing, to which I admit I'm kind of allergic. For example: sitting in silence (could be done on google meet as well, with or without a screen) and then just saying a few words now and then, but allowing the silence to dominate. That can be very powerful. Or deciding to free associate on any word, concept, name, really could be anything, and deciding on that would in and of itself make for an interesting dialogue. Or asking each other questions, but responding with only one or two words, or with a sound, or with silence (you'd say: silence, and then not answer). All this in the interest of getting beyond and underneath the superficial level of things, which when lived in the States, drove me A. crazy and B. into relative social isolation, apart from contacts through work and a relationship now and then, and that is a very long story for another time, or perhaps for never.
So I hope to hear from you. I do of course have a smartphone (just got it, didn't have one before two days ago), and the landline number is below.
Iphone: +36305676368. It's not on all the time because the battery isn't in great shape, so if you want to call, call the landline (+ 36 1 395 8751) and just tell me to switch it on and I will.

ï»¿Intro
Well hi there. Looks like you've stumbled into my "date-me doc." Welcome, please pull up a chair and get comfy while you peruse my ramblings. 

Basics (get your checklist ready)
Age: 39
Height: 5â€™4â€
Location: Manhattan, NYC
Build: Curvy/Athletic
Hair: Auburn with blue/green on the back half of my head. Itâ€™s a cool girl â€œmulletâ€
Eyes: Green
Education: BA in Creative Writing/Poetry, minor in Film Studies
Job: Pricing and Yield management, SiriusXM/Pandora Media (left AND right brained!)
Relationship stats: Never married, looking for monogamous marriage/partnership
Kids: No (human) children, but want.
Autobiographical Ramblings (oh, god, you want to know more??)
I am a born and bred New Yorker. Yes, we exist. Yes, I know how to drive (current Kadi model comes with a bonus car accessory!). Yes, I regularly get out of the city because I know the world is broader than 5 boroughs. I plan on staying in the city since my family and friends are here, and I own my apartment.


I share my apartment with a tiny furry dictator who throws tantrums when he's not getting enough attention, but is somehow cute enough that I haven't returned him to the shelter. His name is Captain Ignatius, or Iggy if you're a friend (you probably are; he's a belly rub whore).


I have been an athlete most of my life (softball, swimming and water polo) and still remain active (kickboxing, gym, rec softball in the park). I love getting lost in a great book or TV show, I geek out on history (NYC history in particular) and 35mm photography. I've traveled some but want to see a lot more of the world, and I'm passionate about human rights of all kinds (LGBTQ, Women's, Black Lives Matter) and animal rights. It is important that my partner understands and supports these as well. I volunteer weekly. I went to a private school in NYC (and hate myself a little bit for having just typed that), and a small liberal arts college upstate. My mother's family is Jewish, but I view that as my culture and not my religion. Iâ€™m an atheist. I don't care if you have religion in your life as long as you don't try to convert me or impose it on our life together. 


I drink and am 420 friendly. I do not smoke cigarettes or cigars and will not date someone who does. I am fairly liberal, so conservatives need not apply. I think common sense is not so common anymore, particularly when it comes to political dogma. I am also always open to thoughtful conversations and debates on most things, so an exact alignment of all my specific values is not a necessity. Respect and morality, however, are.


My friends would describe me as sarcastic, funny, â€œstupid smartâ€[1], loyal, inquisitive, able to name most actors and at least two TV shows/movies they've been in, and "the reason I have a beauty product addiction."[2] And, my personal favorite: â€œI'm trying to figure out a way to say "loud and opinionated" in a way that doesn't sound like an insultâ€[3]
What Iâ€™m looking for (hey, that could be you!)
What I am looking for is a partner in the truest sense of the word. A man with whom I can share my life (and who shares his with me), have a child, see the world, and do all the things. I don't have a laundry list of qualifications, but someone who is settled enough in his life that he's ready to be serious and settle down is important. Non-smoker, non-conservative, not very religious. Able to keep up with my random thoughts, preferably sharing some interests, and willing to also let the furry dictator into your life (weâ€™re a package deal). 
I would prefer a man whoâ€™s at least 5â€™8â€, between 30 and 45, who is based in the NYC area (5 boroughs ideally)
Still here? 
You can reach me at DateKadi@gmail.com, and please include either your own doc or basic details (age, height, where you live, some photos (or social handles)) and what drew you to reach out. I donâ€™t have the ability to answer every email, but I do my best. My socials are locked, and I donâ€™t add randos, sorry! 


Photos!

  





Oh, you want pictures of ME?? Keep scrolling!

What my friends say: borshch
It is hard to have an objective evaluation of a human being, so I found borshch to be the closest proxy for estimating quality of me as future wife.
Borshch is a Ukrainian soup that takes ~2-3 hours to make and is often cooked as a test for marriage readiness. A wife (yes wife, not a man bc men do not cook!!!) is only as good as her borshch (ah, what a great way to reduce human complexity:).
My friend said, â€œthe caliber of a person is determined not by any single borscht they cooked, but that they keep cooking borscht. It is the borscht of the soul that makes the borscht of the stomach.â€
I fed my friends with borshch and asked some follow-up qs.
beware that my subjects are coming with personal bias. One friend even ate meat soup  as vegetarian??!?

Welcome to my Date Me doc, which I must admit feels a bit charmingly low-tech in this Tinder age but hopefully in a cute we-bumped-each-into-each-other-at-the-online-coffeeshop kinda way. I'm Connie, a 33-year-old Chinese American techie person happily settled now in SF* after many years of wandering, Odysseus-style, through half the hokiest small towns in the US. I'm short, monogamous, and usually dressed in an alarmingly varied array of colors:
(me, doing things)
(me, still doing things)
(me, doing something I will definitely never do again)
I'd regale you with tales of my wanderings, but they're honestly quite boring and involve a lot of pet lab mice and early internet fanfic for some reason. The gist of it is that some combination of temperament, parental upbringing, and early Shounen Jump issues led to the dorky, egregiously friendly Huffleclaw you see before yourself today. In my bursts of social fancy I love flittering around novel/weird/interesting-sounding events, philosophy salons, and mysterious houseparties in the Bay, but I'm really an introvert at the core who likes to sun by big windows and nerd out on whatever topic has struck her this week (in my previous life I was definitely a cat, just one of those weirdo bodega ones that like people :P).
I recharge my batteries on all the cozy things - longreads, podcasts, indie movies, coffeeshops and kava bars, bookshops with that old-book smell and perky plants, dinner parties, morning runs by the water and game nights with friends - but will absolutely get hype for the periodic rave, music festival, or good-lord-what-have-I-gotten-myself-into party. I'm high on the openness scale and enjoy poking at new things - even (especially) if they sound a bit out of my comfort zone - though my hope this year is to run around a little less, figure out the things I really care about, and go all in on the people and pursuits that matter to me. Who knows? That could be you ðŸ˜‰
A few pluses about me:
no kids, debt, or crazy exes
likes doing dishes and laundry because that's podcast time ðŸ‘Œ
prefers homey restaurants over fancy ones so cheap date
speaks Mandarin so kids will be set up for the future ðŸ’ª
pretty good at charming old people so your parents will like me
not addicted to tiktok or insta ðŸ˜ƒ (but addicted to reddit instead ðŸ˜”)
decent meme game, if I do say so myself ðŸ˜Ž
My current obsessions in this â€œjust left the city I was in for a decade, hashtag yoloâ€ phase of my life look something like training for a half-marathon, finally learning meditation (or similar in that vein), working on some AI side projects, researching for the book series I keep swearing I'll write, discovering more substacks to hoard in my email, spending a horrifying amount of time on soccer chats (long-suffering Spurs fan hereâ€¦ don't ask ðŸ™ˆ), and making my new home in SF. If I were to pick the one "thing" that really moves me, it'd be the idea of community and how we can better invigorate our society and the platforms we use to foster meaningful relationships, chances for connection, any form of antidote to loneliness that's a little less toxic than some of the tribes that have been forming online. I don't have good answers there but it's a subject I'm very interested in and would love to pick folks' brains on - so if you know anyone engaging in that sphere, I'd be all ears! ðŸ˜Š
What I'm looking for
A thoughtful, kind, kick-ass dude in either SF or NYC also looking for a life partner, a pet or two, and somewhere within one standard deviation of 2.5 kids (I was an only child and I think a sibling-less childhood just really sucks! I want to make a really fun household ðŸ˜).
I'm super into a rigorous, analytical mind (though perhaps less in the sense of traditional booksmarts than street smarts, or a way of thinking outside the box) and curious, driven people who are always looking to learn and grow. Iâ€™ve matched well with honest, assertive, maybe even slightly disagreeable partners who aren't afraid to call me out on things and can balance me out as a teammate (I'll play good cop to your bad cop! The Agent J to your K. The Leslie to your Ron Swanson etc), but I also love goofballs whoâ€™ll text me a terrible meme at 4 in the morning. Itâ€™s stereotypical but oftentimes I think Iâ€™m just looking for someone who makes me laugh ðŸ˜…Â whose values also make me want to be a better person.
I like sporty people. I like nerdy people. I like people who care; I think I'd take that over super â€œcoolâ€ people, as much as I am awed by their badassery sometimes. I love finding the life in people - passion is just delightful! (Even if it's mainly for fantasy football or large language models ðŸ˜†). I can talk your ear off when I'm in the mood, but I LOVE people who can match my energy in conversation and even steer it or relieve my burden when I'm tired; and I think it's a great sign when we can do our own thing in companionable silence and enjoy that too.
Above all else though, I think personal integrity and, like, just giving a shit about people is sine qua non. How someone treats people, whether they keep their word, whether they can navigate the hard times with a steadiness of mind and character is so much more important imho than a few extra points on the IQ scale or zeros in the bank account. I feel the exact same way about close friends, which is why I call my dream life partner as "basically a best friend I'm attracted to and want to raise a family with" - some undefinable formula whose variables are a permutation of friendship, passion, and mutual respect.
Honestly though, I could go on and on rambling here about a shared sense of humor, high bonding-ness, and a level of introversion that agrees to escape a party at the same time, but I do think most of this you're just never going to get off paper because it's really, like, all about the vibes, man. That's not to say dealbreakers don't exist or that compatibility is wholly unpredictable, but I really like waitbutwhy's take on it - a huge part of it is about who you really enjoy being around, and most of that time won't be romantic dates but grocery shopping and waiting for the bus and blobbing on the couch after work. You want someone you enjoy all the times in between the big vacations and dream travel destinations and Burning Mans with - someone you enjoy cooking dinner on the thousandth Wednesday with, or waiting for the Uber with, or rambling about your day to at the end of a long work week. Most of life is the mundane stuff in between the cool exciting stuff, so I'm looking for someone who I can have a mind-boggling amount of fun just Doordashing and watching Celebrity Family Feud with. That's rather difficult to figure out through a few paragraphs and a photo, so really, if this speaks out to you and we seem like a good match - hit me up and let's grab coffee?
Lifestyle compatibility
In a burst of abandon I once signed up for a matchmaking service (note: this did not land me on a Netflix reality show sadly, though it did get me a bunch of spam calls for a year after). The service did not work out as you can probably tell, but what I found interesting about it was that a solid 90% of the intake questions I had to answer was on my lifestyle. I'm not kidding - a quarter might have been about my sleeping habits alone (how late I slept, whether I was a light sleeper, if I needed space in the bed etc).
That has made me think a bit more about lifestyle fit. Having great dates with someone doesn't mean it's easy to live with them, and the latter gets much more important in a serious relationship. I'm sure plenty of folks might not put much stock in any of these, but just in case, I'll list some lifestyle traits of mine upfront:
I'm more of a city gal than a super outdoorsy person, though I do run outdoors almost every day and enjoy a scenic hike or two (and I absolutely love parks!). My favored travel destinations lean towards cities and cultural/historical attractions more than extreme nature spots. Basically I'd pick reading in a cafe or visiting the Louvre over heavy-duty camping most of the time, though Iâ€™m absolutely down for festivals in the woods and cabin trips with  friends.

I'm not a huge gamer, though I've played a few RPGs and enjoy word-based boardgames and co-ops; and as you can tell from the Comic-Con pics, Iâ€™m a long-time anime/manga fan and geek out on a lot of things across the board (scifi, Doctor Who, Marvel etc).
I drink socially, and itâ€™d be nice if my partner could join me there though itâ€™s not a big deal by any means. I'm not a huge foodie or picky but I do try to eat healthily (in moderation!) and am omnivorous with a plant-based lean. It doesn't matter to me if my partner's a serious foodie or vegan or has a lot of restrictions, though if their main hobby is food (e.g. eating out at fancy restaurants every other day) I wouldnâ€™t be able to share in it.
Politically, I'm generally progressive, though eclectically so since I prefer to evaluate an issue in its own context instead of feeling boxed into one broad political platform. I'm open to partners on other parts of the spectrum, as long as there's still a values alignment.
Financially, I try to be pretty frugal on consumables (I donâ€™t eat expensive meals or buy $400 purses) but will absolutely spend money on what I think of as investments: a high-end laptop, Lasik, a course Iâ€™m interested in, anything that makes me more productive at work. I care about experiences, especially the ones best done now (itâ€™s hard to travel when old!) but I think tangible goods have their place in making your life better. Basically, my heuristic is to value the things that will buy me more time with friends. â¤ï¸
Iâ€™d like at least some time to myself most days; I think it's important for couples to have their own hobbies, though I do enjoy parallel play. I don't need my partner to go to everything with me - I can get into really social butterfly moods and if anything I'd much more appreciate having someone to come home to! Later on in a relationship, I'd love a little check-in text/call on days we're apart.
Speaking of - I do love texting ðŸ™ˆ Not a huge deal to me if you don't, but some form of communication most days is pretty important to me. I'd be amped to have someone I can send both serious longreads and dumb twitter memes to, though I don't think there's a need to have a bunch of the same interests - it's more about a similar sense of humor and an interest in the other's life.
My love language is literally conversation, though I might file that more under quality time and companionship than words of affirmation. I love fussing over people and end up doing a lot of acts of service, and the Chinese heritage in me likes to say words are cheap, but my last relationship made me realize how much I value open affection. That's both physical and verbal - I can barely remember what I ate yesterday but almost never forget what someone says to me, for both good and bad (this is NOT to say I demand sappy love letters, just that a sincere word spoken in kindness goes a long way with me ðŸ˜Š).
Hit me up?
First of all, you're the bomb if you actually read this far. And if this clicks with you and you think we might be a good match, hit me up via email, Facebook, or Twitter! If you have a similar kind of profile up somewhere that would be great, otherwise I'd appreciate an intro about yourself and what you're into, what you're looking for, pics or socials etc. Peace! ðŸ––
